quote: This isn't about my work. Do you know what the life expectancy of a Carrington Award winner is? Five years. Ten at the very best. And do you know why? (answering his own question) Because the Carrington Award is intended to be the crowning achievement for a lifetime in medicine. April Wade is a hundred and six. The last time she was nominated, three years ago, people said it was premature.
Julian, you're exaggerating.

Maybe a little. But the undeniable truth is I am far too young to be a serious candidate for the Carrington. Now, put my name up for nomination in seventy years, and I promise you, I will get extremely excited. But until then, I don't plan on giving it much thought.
That's a very mature attitude.
You sound surprised.
Actually, I'm astounded. But impressed.
So then we don't have to dwell on this for the next three days.
I won't mention it again.
I appreciate that, Jadzia.
So who do you think is going to win? Wade or P'Trell?
A cup of millipede juice, hold the shells.
Rom.
Did you call me, brother?
Would it be too much trouble for you to put these empty bottles in the replicator?
Keeping my quarters clean is Nog's job.
Except Nog is on the Homeworld visiting his grandmother.
Then cleaning will just have to wait until he gets back.
No it won't. Until the Nagus gives me back my own quarters, this is my home too. And I've had enough of this mess. Clean it up. Now.
I won't.

Yes you will. It's bad enough I have to put up with your constant teeth grinding every night, and your incessant ear-picking. But I will not tolerate living like some Pakled refuse merchant for another... (he looks at the bottle in his hand) Wait a minute. This is a bottle of Aldeberan whiskey.
Let me, brother.
I recognize this label. This is from my private stock.
No, it's not.
It most certainly is. (sees something else and lets go) And what's that over there?
Trixian bubble juice.
Nog's favorite. This came from my stockroom, didn't it?
Are you accusing my son of being a thief?
No. I'm accusing you of being a thief.
(continuing, re: the cloth) These table linens. The chairs. That table. Everything in here comes from my bar.
Not everything.
As soon as you're done cleaning, I'm going to conduct a complete inventory and find out exactly what you've stolen from me. Now get to work.
No. I refuse. I work for you all day, brother. But here, I'm the boss. You want this place cleaned up, do it yourself.
What I want is my own quarters back.
That makes two of us. Living with you was bad enough when we were children.
What do I do?
You think.
What do you mean, "I think?"
You stay up late, every night, plotting and scheming. And when you think, you mumble. And if there's anything I can't stand, it's listening to you mumble.
That does it. I've been accommodating long enough. If the Nagus wants to stay on the station, he'll have to find someplace else to live.
Are you sure this is a good idea? No one's seen the Nagus since he got here. He must be working on something important. If you disturb him, he might get very angry.
I'm not going to disturb him. You are.
Me? Why not you?

Because Zek likes me. So I can't afford to get on his bad side. On the other hand, he barely acknowledges your existence. So you have nothing to lose. Now go in there and tell the Nagus he'll have to leave. And whatever happens, don't let Maihar'du intimidate you.
Where are you going?
Don't worry, if you need me, I'll be close by.
What can I do for you, Rom?
Grand Nagus, forgive me for disturbing you.
Who's disturbed? I've been hoping someone would drop by. Come right in.
Thank you. We'd be delighted.
Quark. I knew you'd be lurking around here somewhere.
Well what are we standing out here for? I have something very exciting to show you both.
What happened to my furniture?
I got rid of it. It was getting in the way of my work.
And what work was that, Grand Nagus? If I my be so bold?
I'm glad you asked. Maihar'du... the book.
You're about to read the shining triumph of my life. The one thing I'll always be remembered for.
May I?
By all means.
"The Rules of Acquisition, Revised for the Modern Ferengi." You rewrote the Rules of Acquisition?
I hope you like them. Absorb... enjoy...
Rom, do you know what this means?
Yes. It means we're going to have to memorize a whole new set of Rules.
No, you idiot. It means we'll be the first Ferengi to benefit from Zek's wisdom. The knowledge contained in this book could make us both rich beyond our wildest dreams.
I'll be able to go into business for myself. Turn the page, Brother. Turn the page.
The first Rule of Acquisition is...
Go on.
If they want their money back...
Yes, yes?
Give it to them.
If they want their money back... Give it to them?
Rule Number Twenty-One, "Never place profit before friendship." Rule Number Twenty-Four "Latinum tarnishes, but family is forever." Rule Twenty-Eight, "Money can never replace dignity."
Skip to the end.
Well, what is it?
You're not going to like it, Brother.
I can take it. Tell me.
Rule number Two Hundred and Eighty- Five, "A good deed is its own reward."
Brother, are you all right?
I... just need to sit down.
No... Take it away.
Sorry.
Got to think. Got to think. There has to be an explanation... a reason for why he's doing this.
Maybe we should ask him.
No. Don't you see? He's testing us. Yes. That must be it. It's some kind of test. Get the book.
You want to hear more?
No. It must be some kind of code. Read me the first word of every Rule.
If... never... keep... profit... a... good... smile... honesty.
If never keep profit a good smile honesty.
What does it mean, Brother?
It means... absolutely nothing. Maybe if we hold the pages up to the light.
No... that's not it.
The answer must be right in front of us.
I know. Maybe the Nagus has gone insane.
Nonsense. The Nagus is the most brilliant Ferengi alive. I've modeled my life after him. Don't ever let me hear you speak that way about him again.
But what if he really believes all this?

How could he believe this insanity? No. It has to be part of some brilliant, twisted, devious plan. The Nagus isn't like you and me, Rom. He thinks ten, sometimes twenty, steps ahead. These Rules are probably the key component in some vast plot to seize financial control of the entire quadrant.
So what do we do?
The only thing we can do. We put down this book and we walk away.
When the Nagus feels ready, he'll inform us of his plans. But until then, we have to act as if we know nothing.
I can do that.
Don't worry, Rom. In time, all will be revealed.
(still trying to make sense of it) "If never keep profit a good smile honesty." Nah.
Quark, my boy. What do you say we buy everyone a drink? Put it on my tab.
But... why?
Because it will make everyone happy. And that will make me happy.
It must all be part of his plan. Wheels within wheels, Brother.
Drinks for everyone. Compliments of the Grand Nagus. Is there anything else I can do for you, Nagus? We just got in a shipment of quality Hupyrian beetle snuff.

Actually, I've lost my taste for beetle snuff. It might be fun for you and me, but it's no fun for the beetles. By the way, Quark, I just met the most lovely young female. She stopped by your quarters, looking for you.
Was her name Emi, by any chance?
Now that you mention it, I believe it was. She wanted me to tell you that her family's ship has arrived with the latinum.
It's about time. Rom, watch the bar. We're finally going to get rid of those stem bolts.
I don't think so.
But we have a contract.
Which was never signed. And frankly Quark, you were charging an outrageous price for those stem bolts.
She didn't seem to think so.
She did once I explained it to her.
You what?
I couldn't let you take advantage of an innocent young woman like that, Quark. So I told her where she could get all the stem bolts she needed... at wholesale.
Wholesale? He told her where to get them at wholesale.
What am I going to do with a hundred gross of stem bolts?
My poor brother.
Don't worry about him. Eventually, he'll sell those stem bolts... at a fair price.
A fair price? I'm very confused.
That's understandable. It will take some time to get used to the new ways.
New ways?
Walk with me, Rom.
Your turn.
I don't know about this.
Would you rather play racquetball?
Chief, since Keiko's been on Bajor we've played one hundred and six games of racquetball.
Right. So throw a dart.
I'm a little rusty.
So am I.
I suppose the smart money's on Wade or P'Trell.
That seems to be the general consensus.
I mean, Doctor Wade is very popular. But P'Trell is doing some amazing work in gerontological research. Which one do you think will win?
Either of them would be a worthy recipient of the Carrington.
Of course, if I had my druthers, the award would go to you.
Thank you.
But let's face it. You don't stand a chance.
(agreeing, as he takes his turn) You don't say.
I mean, I know how talented you are, but I bet there're doctors all over the Federation saying, "Julian Bashir, who the hell is he?"
Chief, you are absolutely right.
I'm glad you agree.
So... how much longer is Keiko going to be on Bajor?
Hey, Rom...
Open up.
Something wrong, Quark?
My brother should've had this place
Last time I saw him was last night... walking with the Nagus on the Promenade.
Come to think of it, I don't remember him coming back to his quarters last night. I'd better go find him.
Not so fast. Do you have anything to do with this?
The Ferengi Benevolent Association?
This message has been going out over subspace all morning.
This looks like some kind of offer of charitable assistance to those in need.
The operative words being "looks like." I don't know what you and the Nagus are up to, Quark, but I'm not going to let you exploit people in need.
You think this is some kind of scam?
Yes.
I hope you're right.
Make sure the relief shipment is sent by high warp courier. And don't worry about the cost.
Rom, what's all this?
You're looking at the sector headquarters of the Ferengi Benevolent Association.
Brother, I don't have time to talk to you. I have work to do.
That's right, you do. In the bar. And it's time you got started. And make sure the rest of my employees go with you.
That's impossible. You saw how busy they are. I'm afraid you might have to hire some new waiters.
Look, whatever the Nagus is paying, I'll match it.

He's not paying us anything. We're donating our time to help launch the Benevolent Association. I'm the association's senior administrator. You know brother, I never realized how many people there are who could use a little help.
If you don't get down to the bar right now, you're going to be the one who needs help.
The Nagus said you'd react like this.
The Nagus is a very smart man.
He's more than that. He's a visionary. He has plans, brother. And I'm going to be part of them.
What could the Nagus possibly want with you?
He says I'm "malleable." And that he's going to mold me into a new kind of Ferengi. An evolved Ferengi.
Evolved into what?
I'm not sure, exactly. The Nagus says that the answers lie in his new Rules of Acquisition. He told me, "Rom, it's time for the Ferengi to move beyond greed."
Beyond greed? There's nothing beyond greed. It's the purest, most noble of emotions.
"Greed is Dead." That's the tenth Rule of Acquisition.
No it's not. The tenth Rule of Acquisition is "Greed is Eternal."
Not anymore. The Nagus is going to shake the very foundation of Ferengi society, and we're going to be at his side every step of the way.
What do you mean, "we?"
The Nagus has made you the co-chairman of the Benevolent Association. Your name will figure prominently on all our correspondence.
He never mentioned anything about that to me.

The Nagus wouldn't dream of excluding you, Brother. As soon as we get the Benevolent Association established here, the Nagus plans on returning to the homeworld. And we'll go with him. Think of it. You and I will be there when Zek personally announces the "New Rules of Acquisition" on the Grand Steps of the Sacred Marketplace.
We'll be there all right. And we'll probably be right alongside him when they throw him off the spire of the Temple of Commerce.
The Temple of Commerce? But that's the tallest building in the Ferengi Alliance. A fall from that height could... could...
Exactly. Don't you see, Rom. Something's terribly wrong with the Nagus. And we have to help him... before he gets us all killed.
That tickles.
Well, I must say, for a Ferengi of your age, you're in excellent health. That is, aside from some vascular damage to your mucus membranes. You really should stop using beetle snuff.
As a matter of fact, I already have.
Glad to hear it.
Does this mean you're going to have to go in for some exploratory surgery?
Why would I do that?
To find out what's wrong with him.
There's nothing wrong with him, Quark.
That's not true. There's something deeply wrong with him, and you have to find out what it is.

I performed every test I can think of. There's no sign of trauma, brain damage, mental illness. His central nervous system's operating within normal parameters, and his endocrine system's in terrific shape.
You see, I told you. They're like a couple of nervous investors... always looking for trouble. Oh, well. I suppose I should be flattered. Thank you, Doctor. You've been very helpful.
No. He's sick, I tell you. You have to perform more tests.
Quark, if you don't get out of here, I'm going to perform some tests on you.
But you have to do something.
Like what?
Put him in stasis. Keep him from hurting himself until you can figure out what is wrong with him.
I don't think that will be necessary.

I can't believe you're supposed to be one of the five best doctors in the Federation. If you ask me, you're a quack... No wonder everyone says you don't have a chance to win the Carrington. Let's go. Maybe we can make an appointment for you to see Doctor Wade.
Good luck. If I remember correctly, Nairobi is beautiful this time of year.
Here, Doctor. For your trouble.
I can't accept this.
Why not? It's only money. Donate it to charity if you'd like.
And you say he's not sick.
Oh, and Doctor, I do hope you'll attend tomorrow night's ceremony.
Ceremony?
At the Bajoran shrine on the Promenade. I intend to give a gift to the Bajoran people.
Gift. What kind of gift?
It's a surprise. You'll find out tomorrow night like everyone else.
Come along. We have a lot of work
Aren't you done yet?
Breaking into the Nagus's personal shuttle somehow seems wrong, Brother.
I don't care. I have to know what he intends to give to the Bajorans.
But the Nagus wants it to be a surprise.
I hate surprises. Now hurry it up, before someone...
Maihar'du. As you can see, my brother and I were just repairing the door locks on the Nagus's...
(examining it; concerned) This is the gift?
What is it?
It's one of the missing Bajoran Orbs, Rom. An Orb of the Prophets.
I tell you, Rom, this Orb explains everything. Zek's behavior, the new Rules, the Ferengi Benevolent Association, everything.
It does? How?
I'm not sure. But I plan to find out. Don't just stand there. Talk to me.
(pats him on the shoulder) I know how you feel.
What are you doing?
I thought we should look inside... I mean, we don't know for certain that there's an orb in here. Maybe Zek's just giving them the box.
Don't be ridiculous.
But how will we know unless we look?
Rom, it's too dangerous. Now leave it alone.
But Brother--
I said leave it alone.
Rom? Maihar'du? Morn? Anybody?
What's the matter, Quark? Spinning out of control, are we?
Grand Nagus?
Maybe.
Maybe not.
Looking for answers? You couldn't find them if they were dangling from your lobes.
Where's that old Quark cleverness I've heard so much about? Or are you so paralyzed with fear that you can't think straight?
Answer me, Quark. What are you so nervous about? Don't you think change is worth dying for? All I want is a little... leap of faith.
Nice catch.
That's the wonderful thing about mysteries. Sometimes the answers just... fall from the sky.
What do you have to lose? Open it.
Consider it a gift.
Are you all right?
A gift.
A gift?
Zek said the New Rules were a gift.
A gift from Zek to the Ferengi people.
No. They were a gift to Zek. From them. Don't you see? They did it. They put the idea for the New Rules in Zek's head. They... changed him somehow.
They did? How dare they? Who are we talking about, Brother?
The Prophets. The aliens that live inside the wormhole. They did this to him, didn't they?
Tell me everything.
Easy, Brother. You know Hupyrian servants take a vow only to speak to their masters.
You're right; get him a handkerchief or something. I'm going to try to break into Zek's personal logs.

According to Zek's logs, he obtained the Orb from one of his contacts on Cardassia Three. From there, he headed straight for the wormhole. His ship's log shows that he entered the wormhole, stayed inside for only a few minutes, then reversed course, and came here.
You think he went in there to talk to the Prophets?
In his personal logs, Zek said that the future was looking very bright indeed. Don't you get it?

According to Dax, the Wormhole Aliens can see through time. The Nagus must've thought he could convince them to let him see the future. That way he'd be able to anticipate economic changes throughout the galaxy.
The opportunity for profit would've been enormous. But instead he created the New Rules of Acquisition. Why?
Something must've gone terribly wrong. But I intend to set it right.
How, brother?
I have an idea.
Does it involve me?
Not really.
I like it.
May I join you, Doctor?
By all means. What can I do for you?
It's what I can do for you.
I have a friend at Starfleet Intelligence. And she has a friend who has a cousin who's married to the assistant of one of the members of the Federation Medical Council.
Really?
And according to my friend, her friend heard something from his cousin that his wife heard from this council member that I thought you might find interesting.
Which is?
Doctor Wade is not going to win the Carrington.
Not you too.
Doctor, I thought you'd be delighted.
If what you say is true, and mind you, I'm not saying it is, the only one who has reason to celebrate is Ghee P'Trell.
Perhaps. But P'Trell is by no means as popular as Doctor Wade.
According to your friend.
Actually, according to my friend's friend's--
I get the picture.
The point is, if it isn't going to be Doctor Wade, it could be anyone. P'Trell, Senva, Roget, even you.
Constable, I didn't think I was going to win before. And I don't think I'm going to win now.
Is that a fact?
Then why have you been working on your acceptance speech?
How did you know?
Just a guess.

My goodness, I never knew solar flares could be so devastating to a planet's agriculture. Let's see, at current market rates two thousand tons of Kohlanese barley would cost me a hundred and eighty- nine bars of gold press latinum... but it's worth it. I can have the first shipment of barley on the way to you in...
Hold on. I'll be right back.
Can I help you boys?
Wait. I have to be sure that he's all right.
Grand Nagus, can you hear me? Are you okay?
Don't worry, Quark. I forgive you.
You hear that? (more determined than ever) We have to help him.
Brother, this is a very brave thing you're doing.
Taking the Nagus back to the wormhole. I wish I could come with you. But I can't. Good-bye.
Go on. Get out of here. Before you have me crying too.
Don't worry. (he gives the sack a reassuring pat) It's going to be okay.
You know, my boy, I should be very angry with you...
Are you?
Not in the slightest. I can't help myself. I like you. Now, where have you taken me?
Into the wormhole.
What's going on?
This is exactly what happened when I was in here the last time. The wormhole aliens are delightful people, but they like their privacy.
So you did meet them. How did you make contact?
I see you've brought the Orb of Wisdom with you. That should do the trick. If you really want to get their attention, open the box. That's what I did.
Sounds simple enough.
Better hurry. I got the dampening field on this ship for a substantial discount.
Hello?
Hello? Is anyone there?
It is corporeal...
Doctor? What are you doing in here?
A physical entity...
Not another one.
I get it. You're the Wormhole Aliens? Or would you rather be called the Prophets? I never could figure that one out.
Did the Sisko send you?
Sisko? What does he have to do with anything?
The Sisko taught us about corporeal lifeforms.
About linguistic communication.
And linear time.
I know all about it. He's quite a guy. But I'm not here to talk about Sisko.
Then why are you here?
I'm here to talk about the Nagus.
The Nagus?
The other Ferengi who visited you. The one who brought the Orb.
He came to see you, to ask for help. He wanted to learn about the future.
The Zek wanted to know the outcome of the game before it was played.
That's right. (a beat, trying to sound nonchalant) So what went wrong?
At first we did not understand the Zek's request. The Sisko said that corporeal beings value their linear existence.
But the Zek wanted to understand events outside the restrictions of linear time.
He wanted to see the future so he could gain by it.
Yes. The Zek explained the value of "gain." How more is preferable to less.
He taught you about profit.
We found the concept... aggressive.
Adversarial.
Dangerous. We could not comprehend how any species could lead such a barren existence.
It has its advantages.
We do not agree. We found the Zek's adversarial nature... invasive... threatening.
We examined your species' history... the totality of your existence. We discovered that you have not always been as you are now.
We haven't?
There was a time when your peoples' acquiring nature was not so pronounced.
Wait a second. Are you telling me that you somehow... de-evolved the Nagus?
We restored the Zek to an earlier, less adversarial state of existence.
You can't do that. The Nagus is the financial leader of billions of Ferengi. I demand you re-evolve him immediately.
You are adversarial too.
Aggressive. Intrusive.
We should do to this one what we did to the other. Restore it to a purer existence.
Counteract its adversarial nature.
Wait. Let's not be hasty. There's nothing wrong with acquiring profit.
That is what the Zek said.
And he was right. Look, I don't know how you people live, but all of us corporeal, linear whatevers have certain things in common. And one of those things is... The need to improve ourselves.
Our ambition to improve ourselves motivates everything we do.
Your argument is specious. Changing you will not result in the termination of all corporeal existence.
All right, so maybe I exaggerated a little.
We should alter this one and return it to its own people.
Agreed. It is best to avoid contact with this species.

Wait. If you don't want to have any more contact with the Ferengi, that's fine with me. But by altering me, you won't be avoiding contact, you'll be encouraging it. My people are very inquisitive. If you change me, they're going to want to know what happened. And they're going to come here to find out. Just like I came to find out what happened to Zek.
(to the others, acknowledging his point) That is... linear.

And potentially very annoying to you. But on the other hand, if you leave me alone, and put the Nagus back the way he was when you met him, I guarantee that you'll never have to speak to another Ferengi again. So... what do you say?
Linguistic communication is tiresome.
My point exactly. Which is why I think you should send me --
Quark, are you all right?
(still a little stunned by the experience) I think so. What about you?
Stop toadying up to me, Quark. It's revolting. Just get me out of here. I have an Orb to sell to the Bajorans.
Did you say sell?
I'm going to make them pay through the nose.
And speaking of noses, where's my beetle snuff?
Oh, Nagus. You're back. I'm so happy.
You're wrinkling my suit.
Whatever you say.

And now, it is with great pride, that I present the nominees for this year's Carrington Award. They are: Doctor April Wade, Senva of Vulcan, Doctor Henri Roget, Chirurgeon Ghee P'Trell, and Doctor Julian Bashir.
And the winner is...
And the winner is Doctor Henri Roget.
Roget?
How could they give it to Roget?
Better luck next time.
Maybe in forty or fifty years.
You seem to be handling this very well.
(aside to her, still smiling to the others) Believe me, I'm not.
I didn't think so.
Remember what I said, Quark. If anyone asks, you have no idea what happened to the charity money.
You can count on me.
And you're sure every copy of the revised Rules of Acquisition has been destroyed?
The only place the new Rules exist is inside my head.
Don't worry. Within a week, he'll have forgotten them all.
He'd better.
I don't believe it, Brother. After all you did for the Nagus, he never even thanked you.
He doesn't have to thank me. He's the Nagus.
There's only one thing that bothers me. Don't get me wrong, I was honored to help the Nagus, but it would've been nice if I'd been able to make a little profit for my troubles.
That's all right. I made enough profit for the both of us.
What are you talking about?
I'm talking about the Ferengi Benevolent Association. Did you know it was funded with Zek's personal fortune? I was the senior administrator, brother.
You embezzled money from the Nagus.
Surprise.
Father would be proud.
May I help you? You might as well come in.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I'm sorry to bother you, it's just that... I... I've been...
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: You're hurt.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I must've scraped myself on a branch.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: That's what happens when you go tromping around the bayous in the middle of the night.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Go warm up by the fire. I have a first aid kit around here somewhere... Now where is it... ?
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: So... what are you doing out here, anyway?
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I'm a writer... -- at least, I want to be. (decides to come out with it) And the truth is... I was looking for you...
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Oh?
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: You are Jake Sisko... the writer?
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I can't believe I'm really here. Talking to you. You're my favorite author... of all time.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: You should read more...
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I mean it. Your books... they're so insightful...
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I'm glad you like them.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: There. Good as new.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Thank you.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I didn't realize people still read my books.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Of course they do. A friend recommended Anslem to me and I read it straight through, twice in one night.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Twice in one night... ?
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: It made me want to read everything you'd ever written, but when I looked, all I could find were your "Collected Stories." I couldn't believe it.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I'd finally found someone whose writing I really admired, and he'd only published two books.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Not much to show for a life's work, is it? I'm going to get us some tea.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I savored those stories, read them slowly, one each day. And when I was finished, I wished I hadn't read them at all.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: So that I could read them again... like it was the first time.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: There's only one "first time" for everything, isn't there? And only one last time, too. You think about that when you get to be my age. That today might be the last time you... sit in a favorite chair... watch the rain fall... enjoy a cup of tea.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Can I ask you something... ?
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Why did you stop writing?
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I lost my favorite pen... just couldn't seem to get any work done without it.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: You're joking.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: You weren't even forty when you stopped writing... I've never understood why you gave it up.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: It's a long story...
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I have time. Tell me. Please.
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: If you'd shown up yesterday, or last week... I'd have said no and sent you on your way. But here you are, today of all days. Somehow... it seems like the right time for me to finally tell this story...
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: It begins many years ago... when I was eighteen... and the worst thing that could happen to a young man happened to me... my father died...
scene: 1    INT. JAKE SISKO'S HOUSE - NIGHT (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: We were very close, my father and I. Partly because we'd lost my mother five years earlier...
I know. I read a biography about you.
It said you stopped writing so you could conduct scientific research... ?
It's not... quite that simple...

You see, right before my father died, I was working on a short story. I don't remember what it was about... but I do know that I was taking it very seriously. I worked on it night and day for weeks... but I couldn't seem to make any headway, and it was making me miserable.
I suppose my father thought I needed to take a break, because he insisted I come to the Gamma Quadrant with him to watch the wormhole undergo what they call a subspace inversion...
scene: 6    INT.  DEEP SPACE NINE - JAKE'S BEDROOM (PRESENT)

quote: Of course what he didn't realize was that I could hide away on the Defiant just as easily as I could on the station...
Yeah.
Come on, Jake. This only happens once every fifty years. You'll never forgive yourself if you miss it.
I'll be right there.
You said that ten minutes ago.
I just want to get this paragraph right.
I thought you were going to put that aside for a while.
I tried, but it's all I can think about.

I'm no writer, but if I were, it seems to me that I'd want to poke my head up once in a while and take a look around... see what's going on. It's life, Jake; you can miss it if you don't open your eyes.
What do you say we go up to the bridge, watch the wormhole do its thing, then I'll read what you've got and we can talk about it. Deal?
Deal.
Sisko to Bridge. What happened?
The wormhole's gravimetric field is surging...
Pull us back to a safe distance.
I'm on it, Benjamin. But we've got another problem. Power output from the warp core just jumped off the scale.
Sisko to Engineering. Engineering, report.
Dax, I'm going to find out what's happening down there. Stay here.
Most of the time, I knew enough to do what my father told me... but that day, for some reason, I didn't...
Sisko to Sickbay, I need a medical team down here right away.
Dax to Sisko, the warp coils are locked into a feedback loop... You've got to realign them or the core's going to blow...
I'm on it.
Jake, get me an interphasic compensator.
Warning. Warp core breach in fifty seconds.
Dax, you'd better stand by to eject the core.
We can't. The ejection system is off-line.
Where's that compensator?
It's not here... got it.
Warning. Warp core breach in thirty seconds.
I'm going to try shunting the excess power out through the deflector array.
Just a little more...
There...
No!
He was gone...
I'm not sure I could ever get over losing someone like that, right in front of my eyes...
People do. Time passes, they realize that the person they lost is really gone... and they heal.
Is that what happened to you?
No... I suppose not.
There was a memorial service aboard the station.
People came forward and talked about my father, what they remembered most about him... why they would miss him...
I didn't step forward... I couldn't... I felt that no matter what I said about him, I'd be leaving so much more out... and that didn't seem right...
Everyone went out of their way to look after me, especially Dax. She was my father's closest friend, and I guess she felt responsible for me. After a few months...
... things started returning to normal... for everyone else, that is...
I tried to put on a brave face... I didn't want people worrying about me more than they already were...
I'm almost done. We have Holosuite Three for half an hour.
Great...
Nog, get down to the storeroom and bring up five kegs of Takarian mead.
Yes, Uncle.
Sorry, it looks like we're going to lose our holosuite reservation.
You know, Nog, things seem to be slowing down a bit.
I'll have someone else bring up the kegs. You and Jake go have some fun.
(looking around at the hopping crowd) Are you sure?
Go. Now. Before I change my mind.
Next time we go ion surfing, remind me to keep clear of those whip curls.
I don't know if I really want to try it again...
You know, Jake... I'm going to be gone soon... we probably won't see each other for a while.
I know...
So... what are your plans?
I was thinking about taking that deferred admission and going to Pennington in the fall...
That'd be great. We'd both be on Earth.
But maybe I'll just stick around here... I haven't decided yet.
It's late... I think I'll turn in...
Okay...
Jake... ?
Dad... ?
What... what happened... ?

I told Dax about what'd happened... how it felt so real... not like a dream at all... -- and she very kindly obliged me and did a thorough scan of my room. I felt vaguely ridiculous... like a child insisting his parents check under his bed for monsters.
She said it was probably just a nightmare, and I did my best to put the whole episode out of my mind.
I puttered around the station for the next eight or nine months. Nog was off at Starfleet...

-- my stories stubbornly refused to write themselves... so I filled my time playing dom-jot... and trying not to think about how alone I felt... Dax and the others were worried about me... but before long, they had bigger things to worry about.
Tensions with the Klingons were continuing to rise...

My father was a kind of religious figure to the Bajoran people, and when he died, they took it as a sign from the Prophets that the Federation wouldn't be able to protect them from the Klingons. Eventually, Bajor entered into a mutual defense pact with the Cardassians, and the Klingons didn't like that at all.
There are plenty of seats on the transport, and there's another one leaving in just two hours. That's it, move along... thank you.
The station's civilian population was leaving en masse... they knew that if war broke out against the Klingons, Deep Space Nine was going to be on the front line.
Jake, where are you going... ?
I thought I'd watch the ships leaving from one of the upper pylons...
You should be on one of those ships.
I don't have to go, do I?
This is a voluntary resettlement, not an evacuation.
But it would be prudent for you to leave at this time.
I suppose I wasn't feeling very prudent that day... because I ignored their advice...
Jake... ?
I want to talk to you about something.
I spoke with your grandfather... he told me he'd asked you to come live with him.
Even if this sector weren't on the brink of war, I'd still like to see you leave the station.
I'm not going anywhere.
Jake... if I wanted to, I could order you to go.
Please don't make me leave. Not yet. This is my home.
When Dad and I came here, this place was just an abandoned shell; he turned it into something. Everywhere I look... it's like I'm seeing a part of him.
If I leave... I won't have anything left of him...
All right, stay a while longer if you want. But promise me that when the time comes and I tell you to go, you'll do it.
Dad... ?
It wasn't until I actually touched him that I knew... this wasn't a dream...

But there was no time It looks like his temporal for reunions -- something signature has been altered was wrong. I didn't somehow... understand everything they were saying, but DAX Dax and the others seemed to think that the The energy discharge... accident had somehow knocked my father's O'BRIEN "temporal signature" out It must've interacted with of phase... the graviton pulse.

Dax and the others seemed to think that the The energy discharge... accident had somehow knocked my father's O'BRIEN "temporal signature" out It must've interacted with of phase... the graviton pulse.
"temporal signature" out It must've interacted with of phase... the graviton pulse.
And altered his temporal signature.
signature.
Then he must've phase shifted into subspace...
shifted into subspace...
Benjamin, what's the last thing you remember... ?
you remember... ?
I was in Engineering... on the Defiant... feels like a few minutes ago...

character: I was in Engineering... on the
quote: Defiant... feels like a few minutes ago...
minutes ago...
Dad, it's been over a year since the accident.
A year... how can that be?
We think that the warp core discharge pulled you into subspace. If we're right, that would explain why you didn't experience the passage of time...
According to these readings, unless we can find a way to re- align your temporal signature, you'll be pulled back into subspace within a few minutes.
Maybe we can set up some sort of containment field...
Hey... They'll have me fixed up in no time...
How are you doing?
It's all right... everything's going to be all right...
I thought it was a dream...
What was?
When I saw you in my quarters... I should've known you were still alive... I should've felt it...
It's not your fault, Jake. I'm here now... that's what matters.
We're losing him --
Look at me. I need to know that you're going to be all right.
Chief, I need that containment field now...
Field active...
Jake...
It's not working, Chief...
Dad...
I'm going to try locking onto him with the transporter...
Don't leave me...

I didn't think anything could be worse than losing him that first time on the Defiant... until I was standing there staring down at that empty bed... knowing that he was alive, trapped somewhere that existed outside time...
I... can't imagine what that must've been like for you...
What's wrong...
Can I get you something... ?
No... nothing.
Telling me all this is hard for you. Maybe I should come back some other time?
No... there won't be another time.
You see... I'm dying...
I've upset you... you have to understand, when a man my age says he's dying, he's just admitting to the inevitable...
Besides, we older people sometimes like to remind everyone that they should pay special attention to us...
If that's what you're up to you shouldn't have bothered. You have my attention already.
You're a good listener... that's important in a writer.
I'm not a writer yet.
You make it sound like you're waiting for something to happen that'll turn you into one.
I'm not waiting. I'm doing a lot of reading.
You know, to see how it's done. And I'm still trying to figure out what it is I want to write about.
I see...
What happened? With your father, I mean. Did you ever see him again?

For the next few months Dax and O'Brien worked to find a way to locate him. They considered trying to recreate the accident, but that was impossible since the wormhole wasn't going to undergo another inversion for decades. Eventually the situation with the Klingons came to a head, and the Federation decided to turn over control of the station to the Klingon Empire.
There was nothing I could do. I had to leave my home of five years...
And give up whatever hope there was of seeing my father again...
I'm sorry...
Did the Klingons ever contact Starfleet to say that your father had reappeared?
No...

I was left with no choice but to try to get on with my life. I went to Earth, drifted around for a few years, and eventually ended up studying writing at the Pennington school. After I graduated, I settled here in Louisiana so I could be near my grandfather. He had a restaurant in the French Quarter, you know.
I've been there. It's still called "Sisko's." And on the wall there's a copy of the letter your publisher sent you when he accepted your first novel.
Grandpa was always showing off his "famous" grandson. He was every bit as proud of me as my father would've been.
You wrote "Anslem" in this house, didn't you?

At that desk over there. It came out to generally favorable reviews... and little by little, I began to think less and less about the past. Eventually I met a woman, fell in love, and married... for a while, this house was a happy one...
I'm back...
Korena...
Nog, I didn't realize you were here already... I was trying to finish a painting before the light changed and I guess the time got away from me.
It's good to see you...
You too. Did you start the grill... ?
What are we having?
Blackened redfish... fresh from the bayou.
Fish... when these woods are crawling with perfectly good slugs?
I suppose you're going to ask me to chew your food for you... ?
I have to admit I've been more popular with women since I stopped asking them to do that.
I tried to tell you that twenty years ago.
I'm a slow learner...
I'm going to get some champagne.
I'm glad you're here, Nog...
I see you've got another pip on your collar. You keep this up you'll make captain by the time you're forty.
Last time we talked you mentioned you might be heading to the Bajoran Sector.

The Klingons agreed to let Starfleet send an expedition through the wormhole... they said it was in the spirit of scientific exchange, but I think they were happy to have us test the waters in the Gamma Quadrant after all these years -- find out how the Dominion would react to ships coming through.
Did you see the station?
I'm sorry to say it's looking a little run down these days.
But you'll never guess who's still there.
Not... your father?

No, he and my Uncle left years ago. Quark finally got that little moon he was always talking about, and my father, as usual, is making sure it doesn't fall out of orbit... But Morn is still there... running the bar.
Talking his customers' ears off and drinking himself out of business, I'll bet.
Well... why don't we get to the point of today's little celebration...

(raises his champagne glass in a toast) To my dear friend Jake Sisko, winner of this year's Betar prize for his "Collected Stories." May the years continue to be good to you, may your muse... -- continue to inspire you...
And may someone make a holo- program out of one of your stories so you can start raking in the latinum!
Are you all right? Do you want me to call a doctor?
No.
I'll be fine...
You should rest...
No... you came a long way to find out why I stopped writing, and you deserve an answer...
Later that night, after Nog had left...
I stayed up working. My new novel was going well, and when it's going well you don't want to stop...
Coming to bed?
I'm not tired.
Neither am I.
I want to ask you something... How would you feel about designing the cover of my new book?
Do you mean it?
What is it?
Jake... ?
Did you get through?
I talked to someone at Starfleet Science; they're going to get a team here as soon as they can.
This is Korena... my wife.
Your wife...
I never thought I'd have the pleasure of meeting you.
The pleasure's mine. How long have you two been married?
Seven years.
Do I... -- have any grandchildren?
Not yet.
We were married in New Orleans, in your father's restaurant.
He insisted. Just about everyone came. Dax, Kira, O'Brien...
That must've been something...
I'm going to call Starfleet, see what's taking so long.
Jake. They'll get here as soon as they can. Talk to me. I've missed so much. Let's not waste what little time we have.
I have a feeling you might want to see these... they're Jake's.
You did it. I always knew you would...
Hey...
I'm sorry....
What for... ?
For giving up on you...
No one could've been expected to hold out hope for this long.
I should've kept trying to find you... instead I just went on with my life...
And I'm proud of what you've accomplished.
None of it matters. Not when I know you're still lost out there...
Of course it matters... you have a career, a wife. And don't think that just because I'm not around much I don't want grandchildren.
Within a few seconds, he was gone again...
I... don't know what to say...

You don't need to say anything. Just listen, because there isn't much time, and there's still so much left for me to tell you. I consulted with Dax and we realized that the accident must've created some sort of subspace link between my father and me.
That's why he always appeared somewhere near you; even if you were hundreds of light years from where the accident happened.

We also realized there was a pattern to his appearances; they were governed by fluctuations in the wormhole's subspace field. Dax's calculations showed that the next time he appeared, I'd be an old man. I decided to put aside my novel and try to find a way to help him. And so, at the age of thirty- seven, I went back to school and started studying subspace mechanics.

At first Korena was very patient... she supported what I was trying to do. But I got so caught up in my work I didn't notice I was losing her. By the time I became a graduate student, we weren't living together anymore. And by the time I entered my doctoral program, it was over between us.
But I pressed on with what I was doing... And one day, years later, it hit me. I figured out a way to recreate the accident.
It'd been almost fifty years, and the wormhole would soon be undergoing another inversion. There was only one other thing I needed.
The Defiant... Nog was a Captain by then, and he managed to call in a few favors at Starfleet Command and got it pulled out of mothballs...
Worf threw his weight around with the Klingon High Council, and they gave us permission to enter the Bajoran system.
Take us out of warp...
I think I remember how to do that...
I haven't worked a two-dimensional control panel in a long time... how did we manage... ?
We always seemed to muddle through somehow...
Look...
Maybe after we've got Captain Sisko back, we should all drop by Morn's for a drink...
I'd designed a subspace flux isolator...
And we set it up in Engineering.
Are you ready over there, Dax... ?
As ready as I'll ever be, considering the replicators were just about the only things still working when we came aboard.
It's a lucky thing too... These days, Dax isn't much good to anybody without a cup of coffee in her hand.
It's the only thing that kept me awake while you prattled on about your latest paper, or your new backhand, or your kid's science projects...
We're picking up temporal distortions in the subspace field...
The wormhole's beginning to invert...
According to our readings it's going to kick out a gravimetric wave like the one that almost destroyed the Defiant last time...
Don't worry... I've modulated the shields to channel the wave's energy into this apparatus.
Once subspace begins to fragment, we'll try to locate the captain.
Since the accident created a subspace link between him and Jake, we'll have a path of "bread crumbs" to follow...
I'd better get back to the bridge. Good luck...
The wormhole wouldn't undergo another inversion for decades, so this was my only chance...
Subspace field fragmentation is beginning...
It's working...
I think I've located the captain's signature...
Something's happening... I'm losing him...
We're losing them both... they're being pulled into subspace...
Jake... how long has it been... ?
Fourteen years...
What is this place... ?
I don't know...
We could be inside some sort of subspace fragment...
Sisko to Dax... Can you read me?
I brought the Defiant back to the wormhole... we're trying to rescue you... Dax, if you can hear me, try to lock onto my signal...
Look at you... you're older than I am...
Dammit. Why can't they lock on to us?
Jake, they're doing everything they can. There's nothing we can do from here. It's been so long. I need to know what I've missed. What about those grandchildren we talked about?
Korena and I... we're not together anymore. She left me...
I'm sorry...
I shouldn't have let her go... but there was so much I had to do; this has taken years of planning.
What about... your writing?
(slapping angrily at his combadge) Dax. Try boosting the carrier amplitude... maybe you can...
Jake... what's happened to you... ?
This is the last chance I'll ever have to help you...
No...
Listen to me... it's over... it's not going to work...
It has to.
Let go, Jake. If not for yourself then for me. You still have time to make a good life for yourself.
Promise me you'll do that... promise me.
I want you to see something. Go over to my desk...
Go ahead...
It's a collection of new stories...
I decided to honor my father's request and try to rebuild my life... writing these stories was the best way I knew to do that.
I want you to have a copy...
Let me get you one.
Can I have these, instead?
If you want, but they have handwritten notes all over them.
I know... I want to study them... so I can see the changes you made...
Because you want to be a writer someday.
Can I ask why you haven't published these?
I was still tinkering with the last one just this morning. Besides, if you publish posthumously no one can ask you for rewrites.
I was hoping to be able to finish another two stories, but there just wasn't enough time.
You keep saying that there's no more time.

You see, Melanie... after the attempt to rescue my father failed, I spent months trying to figure out what went wrong. Eventually, I came to understand the nature of what was happening to him. It was as if he was frozen in time at the moment of the accident, and the link between us was like an elastic cord. Every so often, it would become taut enough to yank him forward to my time. But only for a few minutes.

I realized that if my motion through time came to a stop, the cord would go slack, and he'd be lost in subspace forever. But if I could cut the cord when the link was at its strongest... when we were together, he'd return to the moment of the accident.
Your father's coming here, isn't he? Soon.
Yes...
You're going to cut the cord... aren't you?
I want you to promise me something.
Anything.
While you're... "studying" my stories... poke your head up every once in a while and take a look around... see what's going on. It's life, Melanie...
And you can miss it if you don't open your eyes...
Thank you... for everything...
It was a pleasure meeting you, young lady.
Jake...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I've been expecting you...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: I'm glad you're still in this house... You seemed happy here... And this... I can't tell you how good it makes me feel to see you got back to writing...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Jake... what is it... ?
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Look at the dedication...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: "To my Father, who's coming home... " Thank you... but... I don't understand...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: It was me. It was me all along. I've been dragging you through time like an anchor... and now it's time to cut you loose...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: What are you saying... ?
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: It won't be long now...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Jake... no...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: When I die, you'll go back to where this whole thing began... you just have to remember to dodge the energy discharge from the warp core...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: You could still have so many years left...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: No... we have to be together when I die...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Jake... you didn't have to do this... not for me...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: For you... and for the boy that I was... he needs you more than you know...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Don't you see? We're going to get a second chance...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: Jake... my sweet boy...
scene: 56   INT. JAKE'S HOUSE - MINUTES LATER (DISTANT FUTURE)

quote: You okay?
How'd you know that was coming... ?
I guess... we were just lucky this time...
Dad, are you all right?
I am now, Jake... I am now...
Captain Sisko. The time is oh-six- hundred.
Acknowledged. Lights.
Do you always get up at oh-six- hundred?
I like to get an early start. But you can sleep in if you want.
Sleep in? I usually get up at five. When you're a freighter captain, you don't have the luxury of lying around in bed all day.
If you usually get up that early, why do you look so sleepy?
I don't usually stay up until one A.M.
Sorry about that.
I'm not.
I'd better get going. You free tonight?
I think I can fit you into my schedule.
I'm counting on it.
Worf to Major Kira.
This is Kira.
Major, you've got an incoming transmission from a Razka Karn. He claims to be an old friend.
Put him through.
Razka. It's been a while. How's business?
Let's just say I miss the old days on Bajor. Smuggling may not've been the safest line of work, but it was a lot more exciting than selling scrap metal.
I think you're the only Bajoran I know who actually misses the occupation.
Don't get me wrong. I'm glad the Cardassians are gone. I just wish I'd put away a little more latinum before they left.
I'm sure you did your best. What's on your mind, Razka?
I've picked up a lead on the Ravinok.
Like the last time?
Last time it was just a rumor. This time I have evidence. A fragment of metal. It looks like part of the forward sensor array.
Can you bring it to Deep Space Nine for analysis?
Sorry, but I'm afraid I can't leave the Badlands right now... Important business. You understand.
The Tholians after you again?
Let's just say it'd be better if you came to me.
(not sure she wants to do this) It's been six years. Even if you have found a piece of the Ravinok, that doesn't mean there are any survivors.
There's only one way for you to find out. I'll be waiting.
Item seventeen... Trelos Vren was arrested on the Promenade outside the Klingon Restaurant and is being held on four counts of petty theft.
Trelos Vren? Where have I heard that name?
We arrested him once for attempting to break into the assay office.
And now he's taken up pickpocketing?
Without much success. Though I suppose you have to admire his persistence.
That was a joke.
I'm sorry, Odo. it's just... I might have a lead on the Ravinok.
I know what you're going to say. It's been six years since the Ravinok disappeared. The odds are that everyone aboard is dead.
That all may be true, but it's not what I was going to say. I was going to say... good luck.
Good luck?
You had a friend on board, correct?
Lorit Akrem.

Which means it doesn't matter whether I think there are any survivors, or even whether you think there are any survivors. You're going to go looking for that ship. So all I can say is... good luck. I hope you find them.
Come in.
Captain. Here to see me off?
I'm afraid not. I'd like you to postpone your trip. At least for a day or two.
What's wrong?
Somehow the Cardassian government got wind of your plan to search for the Ravinok. They've asked permission to send someone with you.
And you said yes?
I said I'd talk to you about it. The Ravinok was a Cardassian ship.
Carrying Bajoran prisoners. I'm not stopping anyone from looking. I just don't know why they have to come with me.
The request came directly from the leader of the new civilian government. (trying to give it a positive spin) Nerys, I know this isn't what you had in mind...
... but Bajor and Cardassia have to learn to work together... and that means cooperating on missions like this.
All right. Just tell them I'm not going to wait forever. If their representative isn't here in fifty- two hours, I'm going alone.
I'll be sure they get the message.
So did you and Kasidy have a nice time last night?
I just wish she wasn't leaving tomorrow.
It sounds like you two are getting serious.
I don't know about that. I don't think Kasidy's looking to get serious.
Ben?
Kasidy.
We were just talking about you.
I don't mean to interrupt, but I wanted you to know, I won't be leaving tomorrow after all.
That's great. How long are you going to be here?
That depends on whether I get this new job or not. I've applied for a position with the Bajoran Ministry of Commerce... to captain one of their freighters.
You're going to work for the Bajorans?
If we can hammer out an agreement. It's a terrific opportunity. I get to use my own ship, pick my own crew, and the best part is, I never have to leave this sector.
Where're you going to live?
On my ship, I suppose.
Why don't you stay here? I'm sure Benjamin could arrange some quarters.
That's not a bad idea.
Yeah...
Well, I've got a meeting on Bajor and the shuttle leaves in a few minutes.
I'll see you tonight.
That answers that. She's serious.
Captain, the Cardassian transport Rabol is approaching the station. They're requesting permission to beam their representative directly to Ops.
Someone's in a big hurry.
Permission granted.
Aye, sir.
Ah, Major Kira. I'm ready to leave whenever you are.
We'll be crossing into the Badlands in approximately six hours.
Very good, Major.
Dukat, let's get one thing straight. This is my mission. The only reason you're here is because I agreed to let you come along. When I give an order, I expect you to follow it... no questions asked.
Believe me, Major, I want nothing more than for this mission to be concluded as quickly and efficiently as possible. I leave the details in your capable hands.
Good, then we shouldn't have any problems. There's one thing I still don't understand. Why did the Cardassian government send you?
The Ravinok was under my general command. Those were my troops and it's my duty to try to find them. The question is... what are you doing here?
I knew someone aboard the Ravinok.
One of the prisoners, I assume?
Lorit Akrem.
I see. So you're on this mission for personal reasons.
Something wrong with that?
Not at all. I've found when one is trying to do a difficult job, personal reasons can be quite an incentive. So who was he? A family member, a compatriot... a lover?
Lorit recruited me into the Shakaar Resistance Cell.
Ah... the infamous Shakaar Resistance. We never could eliminate that little group of yours. And it wasn't from lack of trying, I assure you.
I hope you won't take this the wrong way, Major, but I've always admired you.
If you're waiting for me to return the compliment, you've got a long wait.
That's exactly what I mean. You're so determined, so competent. You're the embodiment of the new Bajor. A Bajoran born out of the ashes of the occupation, a Bajoran tempered with Cardassian steel.
Captain Sisko's right. You are in love with the sound of your own voice.
I know it's hard for you to accept, but I think that, in some ways, the Occupation actually helped Bajor.
Which part? The massacres or the strip mining?

I have no wish to debate the merits of the Occupation. I'm even willing to admit that perhaps we were a little too harsh in our methods. But the fact is, the Bajoran people are stronger than they have been in centuries. When we arrived, you were a weak, contemplative race, choking on your isolation. And now you have a new confidence, a renewed sense of purpose, not to mention a key role in the future of this entire quadrant.
All of which Bajor achieved in spite of the Cardassians, not because of them.
Think what you must. But I believe the time will come when Cardassia and Bajor will grow to be not only allies, but also... Close friends.
Cardassia and Bajor... maybe. You and me... I doubt it.
All I ask, Major, is that you keep an open...
All right, Dukat, that's enough. If you don't mind, I'd like to spend the next six hours in silent meditation.
Is that a request, or an order?
Whatever it takes.
In that case, as much as it pains me...
We both might survive this trip after all.
They didn't even wait for the interview to be over. After twenty minutes, Minister Azin said she'd heard enough, and if I wanted the job, it was mine.
So what did you tell them?
What do you think I told them? I said yes.
Congratulations.
That's it?
Oh.
That's not what I meant. I want to know how you feel about it.
I think it's... great. We'll get to see a lot more of each other.
You know, I was thinking about what Dax said. Maybe I should get quarters on the station.
That's a big step.
What does that mean?
I just meant... it's a big step.
A bad big step, or a good big step?
A good one.
Could you muster a little more enthusiasm?
I am enthusiastic. I'm really proud of you. This job...
Forget about the job. What about us? I tell you I'm thinking about living on the station, and all you can say is, "It's a big step?"
I don't think you took that the way I meant it.
I don't think you know what you meant. But I do. You're afraid of commitment.
Who said anything about commitment?
Obviously not you. You know what... forget the whole thing. I'm not going to take the job. If you don't want me to stay here, that's fine with me.
How'd you get a hold of this, Razka?
I bought it from a Ferengi scrap- metal merchant.
It appears to be composed of uridium alloy. Definitely Cardassian.
Can you tell if it's from the Ravinok?
Why didn't you tell me you were bringing him?
When we talked, I didn't know I would be.
Too bad. The Maquis would've paid handsomely to get their hands on him.
And my government would be very happy to get their hands on you.

Razka Karn, if I'm not mistaken. Smuggler, thief, black marketeer. There are at least twelve outstanding warrants for your arrest on Cardassia. But I suggest we ignore all that and try to cooperate with one another.

The voice of the new Cardassia. So compassionate, so understanding. It almost makes you forget that five years ago, he was working Bajorans to death in forced labor camps and shooting anyone who tried to stop him. Almost makes you forget.
It's from the Ravinok, no doubt about it.
Did the Ferengi tell you where he got this?
No. But I was curious. So I bribed one of his crewmembers. Turns out his last trip was to the Dozaria system.
Dozaria. I believe there's a Class-M planet in that system.
Barely Class-M. He found that... In orbit.
Dozaria it is then. Thanks, Razka. I owe you one.
Just let me know what you find out. Lorit was my friend too.
The one thing I don't understand is how the Ravinok could've gotten so far off course. Dozaria is light years from where they should've been.
The Central Command always believed the ship was destroyed in some kind of escape attempt by the Bajoran prisoners.
Maybe. Or they could've had a problem with their navigational array... or run into some kind of subspace anomaly.
Hopefully we'll learn the truth.
I'm reading severe ionic interference in the planet's atmosphere. Sensors will be limited, to say the least.
I'm picking up a faint magneton signature. It could be residual radiation from a damaged warp nacelle.
Shall we beam down?
I wouldn't advise it. The ionic interference would scatter our molecules halfway around the planet. We're going to have to do this the old fashioned way.
It's going to be a difficult landing. If you'd like me to take the controls...
That'll be the day. Going in.
Invigorating, isn't it. A bit "sunny" perhaps, but this heat feels wonderful.
Only a Cardassian could call this hellhole invigorating.
Oh, that's right. I forgot. Compared to us, you Bajorans are a bit... fragile. Physiologically speaking, of course.
Don't worry about me.
The Ravinok.
"It's a big step." That's all you said?
That's all.
You're sure?
Positive.
What do you think, Julian?
It's ambiguous. Definitely open to interpretation. (trying to put things in a positive light) But it could've been worse. He could've said, "It's a very big step."
You didn't say that, did you?
I don't think so.
That's good, anyway. So what does he do now?
It's simple. He goes to Kasidy, admits that everything was his fault, and pledges his undying love.
I don't know. Sounds a little extreme to me. What if he just tells Kasidy he made a mistake... that it was all a misunderstanding. And he really does want her to live on the station.
That could work. Assuming that's what you want.
Captain, I would think long and hard before answering.
I don't recall asking your opinion, Quark.
Maybe you should. I mean, who knows more about women than me?
Everyone.

Fah. You humans, all you want to do is please your women. You want them to be your friends. But we Ferengi know better. Women are the enemy. And we treat them accordingly. The key is to never let them get the upper hand. If she says she doesn't see you enough, threaten to see her even less. If she wants more gifts, take back the ones you've already given her. It's all about control.
And what if your woman leaves you?
That's what holosuites are for.
It's a wonder they manage to reproduce at all.
So, you never answered the question. Do you want her to stay, or not?
I appreciate all the advice. I'll let you know how things turn out.
So, just between you and me, what do you really think about Kasidy moving onto the station?
It's a big step.
A very big step.
They didn't just crash. These are phaser hits.
Looks like she put up quite a fight.
And paid for it.
Twelve graves.
There were eighteen crewmembers and thirty-two prisoners on the Ravinok.
Then what happened to everyone else?
First things first.
What are you doing?
We need to identify these bodies.
I'll help.
No. Our funeral rites are very strict. It would dishonor the dead if a non-Cardassian were to view the remains.
There could be Bajorans buried here too.

No doubt. But if I remember correctly, Bajorans are much more concerned about the souls of the dead than about their physical remains. How did Kai Meressa put it, "What remains after death is but a shell... a sign that the pagh has begun its final journey to the Prophets."
Please, Major... Don't make this any harder for me than it already is.
I have a list of the missing Bajorans. I should be able to identify them by the family imprints on their earrings.
I'll work on the Ravinok. Maybe I can get something from the ship's computers.
You'll need the command codes.
Standard Cardassian military codes from six years ago, right?
I got them from Bajoran intelligence before we left.
Dukat, I was able to reactivate the --
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: Dukat...
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: It's nothing. Nothing at all.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: What was her name?
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: I recognize a Bajoran pledge bracelet when I see one.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: Her name was Tora Naprem. So you see, major, you're not the only one who had a friend on board that ship.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: Friend? Is that all she was?
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: I see. Don't worry, Dukat. You weren't the only Cardassian officer who kept a Bajoran mistress.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: It wasn't like that. Naprem and I... loved each other.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: The head of the Occupation in love with a Bajoran?
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: Ironic, isn't it?
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: Did your wife know?
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: No. And she's never going to find out. If it's all the same to you, major, I'd rather not talk about this right now.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: Here. The earrings you wanted.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: If Lorit's dead, he wasn't buried here. According to the computer logs, the Ravinok was attacked by two unidentified warships. It looks like the attackers chased the Ravinok here, then forced it to crash-land.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: So the survivors could've been captured and taken away.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: Or they could still be here.. Somewhere on this planet.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: We should go back up in the runabout... scan for them from orbit.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: There's too much ionic interference. Our sensors would never be able to pick up their lifesigns. But there may be another way.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: In these conditions, tricorder range will only be about a dozen meters. But that should be enough.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: Enough for what?
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: During the occupation, Bajoran resistance fighters carried subdermal implants of tritonium isotopes. The idea was, if they were captured, they could activate the implant so they could be tracked and rescued.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: I think I've got something. That way.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: Let's go.
scene: 43   EXT. CRASH SITE (LOCATION) - BY THE GRAVES - DAY

quote: Major, please try to keep up.
I'm right behind you.
I don't know why we have to stop.
For one thing, I can't see two meters ahead of us, and besides, we could both use the rest. Now stop pacing and sit down.
What is it?
I don't know. I sat on something.
Let me see.
Get it out.
Hold still and I'll see what I can do.
This is going to hurt.
It already hurts. Just take it out.
If you say so.
Here. Run this dermal regenerator over the wound.
It's not funny.
It is from this angle.
You know what's even funnier... It's not working.
You have to activate it first.
Ahh, much better.
When you're done, you should probably eat one of these.
It's been a long time since I've had field rations. I'm sure they haven't improved a bit.
They've actually gotten a little worse.
Tell me something... Who's Tora Ziyal?

When I reactivated the Ravinok's computer, I downloaded the manifest. There were two civilians on board, in addition to the prisoners and the crew. Your... friend Tora Naprem and a Tora Ziyal, a thirteen year-old girl.
I suppose you wouldn't believe me if I told you she was Naprem's sister?
Ziyal is a Cardassian name. The way I see it, there's only one explanation. Ziyal was Naprem's daughter, and...
And I was her father.
Now I know why you're in such a hurry to find the survivors. You're hoping she's still alive, so you can rescue her.
Not quite. You see... if my daughter is still alive, I'll have no choice, but to kill her.
You know I'm not going to let you do it.
I mean it, Dukat. You're not going to kill that girl.
Major, you worry about the other survivors, and let me worry about Ziyal. After all, she's my daughter.
That's right, she is your daughter. And there's nothing more important to Cardassians than family. At least that's what your people are always saying.
I have a wife and seven children. They're my family. And they're the ones I have to protect.
You should've thought of that before you got involved with Naprem.
You're right. I should have. But I made a mistake. A mistake I intend to correct.
You don't have to bring her back to Cardassia with you. Let me take her to Bajor. No one has to know you're her father.

And what kind of life would that be for her? Your people have never exactly welcomed half- Cardassian children into your society. That's why I sent her and her mother away in the first place. I knew the Occupation was ending, and that there'd be no place for them on Bajor... or Cardassia.
So you sent them to a prison camp.
They weren't headed for a prison camp. The Ravinok was supposed to rendezvous with a freighter which was to take Naprem and Ziyal to Lissepia, where they could live out their lives in peace.
I don't understand. If you cared enough to help Ziyal then, how could you be thinking about killing her now? Why not send her away again?

Because times have changed. My position isn't nearly as stable as it once was. By aligning myself with the new civilian government, I've made many enemies, enemies who wouldn't hesitate to use Ziyal against me.
Listen to yourself. It's not your wife or your seven children you're trying to protect. It's you.
By protecting myself, I protect them.
And the only one who'll suffer is Ziyal. You'd kill your own daughter to save your career.
I don't understand you, Dukat. I saw you crying over Naprem's grave. You said you loved her.

I did love her. And when I bury Ziyal, I'll weep over her grave just as I wept over her mother's. But that won't stop me from doing what needs to be done. And when the time comes, I suggest you stay out of my way.
What's new?
Nog and I ran into Kasidy last night, over at the Vulcan restaurant. I guess she's not taking that job after all.
She told you? Did she say why?
She said you didn't want her to take it.
Look, Jake, sometimes things between men and women can get a little... complicated.
Maybe. But I don't think this is one of those times. It's pretty simple, Dad. You're scared.
What do I have to be afraid of?
A lot. Kasidy's willing to make a major change in her life just to be close to you. If things don't work out, you're going to feel responsible. And that's scary.
You figured all this out by yourself?
Actually, I talked with Nog about it.
You talked to Nog about my relationship with Kasidy?

And we think you have nothing to worry about. If Kasidy wants to change jobs, that's her decision, not yours. Same thing if she wants to live on the station. If things don't work out, they don't work out.
Have you told any of this to Kasidy?
Nog and I thought about it. But we decided it would be better if you told her yourself.
So, what's new with you?
Take a look.
The Breen? What are they doing here?
My tricorder's picking up a large concentration of dilithium in this area. They must be using the survivors from the Ravinok to mine the ore.
It makes perfect sense. The Breen homeworld is a frozen wasteland. This place is about fifty degrees too hot for them.
Are you saying you approve of what they're doing?
Not at all. But I admire their ingenuity.
What is it?
It's her.
My daughter.
We're going to need some help. I'll stay here and keep an eye on things while you go back to D.S. Nine and get reinforcements.
scene: A62   EXT. DOZARIA MOUNTAINS LOCATION - DAY

quote: I have a better idea. You go back to the station and I'll stay here.
scene: A62   EXT. DOZARIA MOUNTAINS LOCATION - DAY

quote: I'm sending you back, Dukat. That's an order.
scene: A62   EXT. DOZARIA MOUNTAINS LOCATION - DAY

quote: And I hate to refuse it. But I'm afraid I have to. You're welcome to file an official protest with the Cardassian military when we get back.
scene: A62   EXT. DOZARIA MOUNTAINS LOCATION - DAY

quote: There's no way I'm leaving you alone here.
scene: A62   EXT. DOZARIA MOUNTAINS LOCATION - DAY

quote: Then I suggest we devise a plan to rescue the prisoners. Together. You need me, Major.
scene: A62   EXT. DOZARIA MOUNTAINS LOCATION - DAY

quote: Maybe I do. But if you hurt that girl... I promise, I'll kill you.
scene: A62   EXT. DOZARIA MOUNTAINS LOCATION - DAY

quote: Don't make any noise. We're here to help.
You're Bajoran.
Gather as many prisoners as you can. Have them meet us here.
How many Breen guards are there?
I'm not sure. There are always at least eight in the mines.
How many prisoners?
There're only thirty-one of us left.
What about Lorit Akrem? Did he make it?
He died in a cave-in. Two years ago.
You knew him?
He was a friend.
My condolences, major. But we don't have time for this. Tell me where I can find Tora Ziyal.
Don't tell him anything.
A Cardassian. I don't understand.
There's a peace treaty.
You mean the Occupation is over?
I need to find the girl. Tell me where she is.
Dukat.
Tora Ziyal. Where is she?
Go get the rest of the prisoners. I'll meet you at the entrance to the mine.
Ziyal.
Father?
It's really you. Mother said you'd come.
Dukat, no.
Father, what's wrong?
I'm warning you, Dukat. Don't do it.
I have no choice.
There's always a choice. You don't want to do this. If you did, you never would've told me about Ziyal. Now put the rifle down.
No.
The Cardassian prisoners... they told me this would happen.
That you'd never let me go home. But I didn't believe them.
Ziyal, run.
I used to dream about you coming to save me. It's what kept me alive.
Ziyal...
If I can't be with you, I'd rather die.
Let's go home.
Kasidy.
Hello, Ben. Hold this a second.
Listen, about that job with the Bajoran Commerce Ministry...
You know someone who's qualified for it?
I know someone who's perfect for it... You. Kasidy, I think you should take the job. I want you to take it.
You've been talking to Jake.
How'd you know?
He's a smart boy. Must take after his mother.
Look, I owe you an apology. You told me all this great news, and all I could say was, "It's a big step." I don't know what I was thinking.
Take a guess.
I wanted to tell you how happy I was for you... and for us. But it didn't come out that way. I was uncomfortable, and a little nervous.
A little nervous?
Okay. A lot nervous. I haven't been in a serious relationship for a long time, and I didn't expect to be in one anytime soon. Until I met you.
But the life I lead, the job I do... that's what got Jennifer killed. If anything were to happen to you...
Why not let me worry about that?
That's what Jake said.
You see... smart boy. Look, I could listen to you apologize all day, but I've got to get to Bajor.
Bajor? I thought...
I know what you thought, but I took the job. You think I'd give up a great opportunity just because you got cold feet?
You're a good man, Benjamin Sisko. But you've got a lot to learn about women... especially this one.
I'll see you when I get back. You can help me pick out quarters.
I'll be there.
So what was it like... all that time alone with Dukat?
I've had better weeks. But I'll never forget the look on his face when he sat on that sand- spine.
I wish I'd been there.
Major...
Dukat. Where's Ziyal?
