scene: 92   INT. ENTERPRISE - CORRIDOR - CLOSE ON SISKO

quote: He wouldn't tell us where this... Tribble is, but he did say it would go off within the hour.
It could be anywhere...
Benjamin, I think we should risk going to the bridge. If we can use the internal sensors, we could scan the entire ship for explosives in a matter of seconds.
Dax and I will take care of the Enterprise. The rest of you beam over to K-Seven and begin searching over there.
Understood. But I think Mister Worf should remain here... it seems that he's... ... allergic to Tribbles.
All right.
Captain, I don't think we'll be able to get to K-Seven's internal sensors.
Then you'll have to manually scan every Tribble on the station.
There must be thousands of them by now.
Hundreds of thousands.
One million, seven hundred and seventy-one thousand, five hundred and sixty-one.
That's starting with one Tribble having an average litter of ten every twelve hours -- after three days you'd....
Thank you. You have your orders, people. Sisko out.
I re-routed the sensor interface.
It worked. I'm scanning the Bridge... Nothing up here.
That's a relief. When Kirk sat on that Tribble, I half expected it to go off.
Nothing on the first six decks...
You wanted to see me, Jim?
I know him...
That must be McCoy -- the ship's Doctor.
McCoy... McCoy...
The nearest thing I can figure out is they're born pregnant. Which seems to be quite a timesaver.
Leonard McCoy. I met him when he was a student at Ol' Miss.
Who met him -- Curzon?
No, my host at the time was Emony. I was on Earth judging a gymnastics competition. I guess he took my advice. About becoming a doctor - I told him he had the hands of a surgeon.
I get the picture. I've scanned every deck -- the bomb's not aboard the ship.
Then it must be somewhere on K- Seven...
Odo here.
The bomb's not aboard the Enterprise... It must be over there.
We've only been able to get through two decks, we're running out of time.
I can send more teams from the Defiant.
It's not a question of manpower, it's a question of multiplication. The Tribbles are breeding so quickly, we can't keep up with them.
Benjamin, maybe we can narrow things down a little. Presumably, Darvin put the bomb somewhere he knows Kirk is going to be in the next half hour. If we stick close to Kirk...
He might lead us right to it.
It's worth a try, but there's no reason for us to stop searching over here.
Keep at it for now, Constable.
Deck Five.
This is my chicken sandwich and coffee.
Fascinating.
I want these things off the ship. I don't care if it takes every last man we've got, I want them off the ship.
Aye, they're into the machinery, all right.
And they're probably into all the food processors too.
How?
Probably through one of the air vents.
Captain, there are air vents of that type on the space station.
And in the storage compartments.
Storage compartments? Storage compartments!
Most of these are dead... The grain's poisoned...
I'm picking up a faint tricobalt signature... the bomb's somewhere under here.
What's that?
Someone's trying to open one of the bay doors.
Benjamin! It's right in front of us... within a meter of where I'm standing.
They appear to be gorged.
Gorged? On my grain?
Kirk, I'll hold you responsible for this. There must be thousands...
Hundreds of thousands.
One million, seven hundred and seventy-one thousand, five hundred and sixty-one.
That's assuming one Tribble multiplying with an average litter of ten...
Found it...
Sisko to Defiant.
It's dead...
Go ahead, Captain.
We found the bomb -- lock onto my tricorder's signal and beam it into space.
Acknowledged...
Kira to Sisko.
It worked.
-- and as captain I want two things done...
First, find Cyrano Jones...
Second, close that door...
After the bomb was detonated, history continued uninterrupted.
Kirk uncovered the truth about Darvin...
scene: 143  INT. K-7 - STATION MANAGER'S OFFICE - CLIP

quote: They don't like you Mister Darvin. I wonder why.
scene: 143  INT. K-7 - STATION MANAGER'S OFFICE - CLIP

quote: Jim, this man is a Klingon.
scene: 143  INT. K-7 - STATION MANAGER'S OFFICE - CLIP

quote: By the time we returned to the Defiant, Major Kira had discovered how to use the Orb to bring us back to our own time.
And that's when you returned the present?
Well... not exactly...
Before we left, I realized there was one last thing I had to do...
Something I'd been thinking about ever since I saw that ship on the viewscreen.
Excuse me, captain.
scene: 147  INT. ENTERPRISE - BRIDGE - CLOSE ON SISKO

quote: Lieutenant... ? Lieutenant... ?
scene: 147  INT. ENTERPRISE - BRIDGE - CLOSE ON SISKO

quote: Benjamin Sisko, sir.
scene: 147  INT. ENTERPRISE - BRIDGE - CLOSE ON SISKO

quote: I've been on temporary assignment here. Before I leave, I just want to say... it's been an honor serving with you.
scene: 147  INT. ENTERPRISE - BRIDGE - CLOSE ON SISKO

quote: All right, Lieutenant. Carry on.
scene: 147  INT. ENTERPRISE - BRIDGE - CLOSE ON SISKO

quote: Now if you want to put a letter of reprimand in my file for that... go ahead.
We'll have to review the case before making any recommendations.
However... I don't think there was any harm done.
I probably would've done the same thing myself.
You'll be receiving our report in about a month. But based on what you've told us... I don't think you have anything to worry about.
I'm glad to hear it.
Good-bye, Captain.
Good-bye.
Docking Port Seven.
It went well?
Good. The constable wants to see us. On the Promenade.
Did you tell them?
They didn't ask.
I'm open to suggestions, people.
We could... build another station.
I want him treated like a visiting head of state. Full communications and computer access, any kind of assistance he might need from the station's crew...
You should've let us know he was coming sooner. I think we've got a red carpet in storage somewhere.

Dax, this is important. Tekeny Ghemor led the dissident movement against Cardassia's Central Command. And now that Dukat and the Dominion have taken over, there's no one better qualified to lead the opposition.
Besides... he's practically your father.
Your father? Isn't Ghemor a Cardassian?
It's a long story.
The Cardassians once kidnapped Kira and surgically altered her to look like Ghemor's missing daughter.
It was part of a plan to expose him as the leader of the dissident movement.
Cardassian politics are very... complex.
I think they like it that way.
Ghemor may be the only hope left for Cardassia. He deserves our help.
That's a lot of faith to put in one man.
I hope I won't prove too great a disappointment.
Legate Ghemor. It's good to see you.
How many times do I have to tell you, Nerys? If you won't call me "father," Tekeny will do.
Welcome to Deep Space Nine... Tekeny. This is our science officer, Lieutenant Commander Dax, and our strategic operations officer, Lieutenant Commander Worf.
Quite an impressive reception for an old man.
You're wearing the bracelet I gave you.
It's... not exactly permitted under the uniform code... but...
It looks good on you.
It's been a pleasure meeting both of you. But if you'll excuse me, I'm afraid the journey here was a little... draining.
I'll show you to your quarters.
Major Kira, friends with a Cardassian. It seems wrong.
You should've known her five years ago. Back then, I never thought she'd be friends with anyone.

I've had the replicator programmed with a complete Cardassian menu. You've got twenty-six-hour-a-day computer access and a private subspace com channel. And if there's anything else you need, just let me know.
I wish I had your energy.
I'm sorry. I wanted you to feel at home.
You've been very kind.
I thought you should know... I checked with Bajoran Security. They still don't have any leads on your daughter.
She's dead, isn't she?
We don't know that. If Iliana's still alive, she's been undercover on Bajor for over a decade. It's not easy to find someone who's been hiding that long.
I know you're trying to keep my hopes up, but it's time I faced the facts. I'm alone. You're the closest thing to family I have left.
Bajoran Security hasn't given up yet. And neither should you. You just have to be patient.
I'm afraid patience is for the young.
What about you, Nerys? How is life treating you?
I've got no complaints. (tries to give him something positive to focus on) Did you read the proposal I sent you?
It was very... ambitious. But I'm afraid you'll have to find another person to lead the effort.
But you're the best person for the job. You're still popular on Cardassia... people respect you... they'll listen to you.
It's not that simple.

We can make it work. We'll set up a government in exile here on the station. You can make regular transmissions into Cardassia, issue corrections to their propaganda, mobilize your old friends in the dissident movement...
Nerys...
It's a good plan. But I can't help you.
Why?
I have Yarim Fel syndrome. It's terminal, Nerys. I'm dying.

(wishing he had better news) I'm afraid the prognosis isn't good. The disease has already spread throughout your digestive tract, your circulatory and respiratory systems, your cartilaginous tissue...
How much time do I have left?
I'm not sure. There're still some procedures we can try. Hexadrin therapy. Or immunoregeneration treatments.
I appreciate anything you can do.
I'm sorry, Nerys. I know this isn't going the way you planned.
Don't worry about me. The important thing is to get you well.
Begin Captain's log, Stardate...
Ops to Sisko.
Go ahead.
You've got an incoming message from Cardassia. It's Gul Dukat. He's "demanding" to speak to you.
Put him through.
Captain Sisko. Always a pleasure.
Still calling yourself "Gul" Dukat? I'm surprised you haven't promoted yourself back to Legate by now.
I prefer the title "gul." Much more hands-on than legate. And less pretentious than any of the other alternatives... president... emperor... first minister... emissary...
How about "Dominion Puppet?"
Captain... such comments only reveal a deep misunderstanding of the intricacies of the Dominion political system. Under our new administration, Cardassia enjoys unparalleled autonomy and...
You can justify yourself later, Dukat. I'm a busy man.
Humans. You have no appreciation for the fine art of conversation.
Very well. We have reason to believe one of our citizens is aboard your station. A certain Tekeny Ghemor, formerly a Legate in the Cardassian Central Command.
And if we do?
We want him back. To put it mildly, he has a lot to answer for.

I'll take your request under advisement. But, considering the Federation doesn't recognize your "government" and that Cardassia has never agreed to an extradition treaty with Bajor or the Federation... I wouldn't get your hopes up.
(baby talk, to Kirayoshi) What a beautiful baby you are. Yes. You must be very proud.
He's Miles and Keiko's baby. I only carried him to term for them.
Maybe you'd better...
Are you...
It'll pass.
It's silly, but I almost feel like a grandfather. After all, you're the closest thing I have to a daughter...
And Yoshi is the closest thing I have to a son. (trying to make him feel better) You'd make a terrific grandfather.
What about you, Nerys? Have you ever thought about having one of your own? Maybe with that Shakaar fellow of yours?
You know about Shakaar and me?
I've been keeping an eye on you. It made me feel like I still had family.
What did you do, hire someone to follow me around?

Credit an old man with some restraint. I just had people let me know when they heard anything about you. Like it or not, you're a public figure... the first officer of one of the most important military installations in the quadrant... Your feud with Kai Winn is already something of a legend. Did you know you have your own section in the Cardassian Central Archives?
I guess I try not to think about it.
You've made an impression on people, Nerys. A good one. You should be proud of everything you've accomplished. I am.
I've kept my ears open for news about you, too. I worried about you. Opposing the Cardassian government is a dangerous business.
I enjoyed it, while it lasted. I have a fondness for hopeless causes. It runs in the family.
Dukat called the station. He wants you extradited to Cardassia.
(fighting another wave of pain) I'm not surprised. He knows as long as I'm still alive, I'm a threat to him.
We're not going to let him get his hands on you.
Nerys, I know more about the Cardassian government than anyone alive. Names, alliances, plots. Things that could do a lot of good, in the right hands.
There's a Cardassian tradition, called Shri-tal.
The dying give their secrets to their family, to use against their enemies. But I have no one left to carry my secrets. No one but you.
Me?
Be my daughter one last time, Nerys. Hear what I know... and use it as you see fit.
I hate to sound callous... but we've got a tremendous opportunity here. Ghemor's basically volunteering to give us more intelligence on Cardassia than we've been able to gather in five years.
That's exactly what he's doing.
It's quite a responsibility he's handing you.

I know. I can't help but wonder if he chose the right person. What if I become too involved... what if don't ask the right questions? Maybe I can convince Ghemor to talk to a counselor... or Constable Odo. He questions people every day.
Maybe. But Ghemor doesn't just want to be debriefed. He wants someone to talk to... someone to be with until the end.
And that someone is me.
Nerys.
Father?
Father, can you hear me?
Are you up to it?
I don't have a choice. I'm all he's got.
If Ghemor's pain gets too severe, push this. It'll administer a small dose of triptacedrine. If you need to replenish the medication, just turn this valve...
Disconnect it here, and insert the new supply. If you don't want to do it yourself, you can always call for a nurse.
I can manage.
I hope you're right. Being with someone with a terminal condition isn't easy. And in a case like this one, where you'll be acting as Ghemor's only source of emotional support...
I know what I'm getting myself into.
I'm sure you do. Let me know if you need anything.
Tekeny...
Nerys...
Don't try to move.
Mouth's dry.
I'll get you some water.
Careful.
Damn it. I'm sorry.
It's all right. You're doing fine. (fighting against the pain) Maybe we should get started.
Session One, Stardate 50712.5.
Probably Dukat's most powerful enemy is Gul Trepar, the head of the Fourth Order. He...
What's wrong?
Button.
Better?
Maybe I can get Doctor Bashir to give you something stronger.
No. Anything stronger and I'd be unconscious... And you and I have a lot to talk about. Where were we?
Trepar.
Trepar. Trepar used to outrank Dukat and he's not happy to be taking orders from one of his former subordinates.
(his words slowly fading into the background) Trepar's aide is a man named Glinn Borven. He's a political opportunist with all the loyalty of a hungry vole.
Medic! I need a medic!
What the hell's taking them so long!
Nerys!
Nerys... don't leave me.
I was such a fool. When the Cardassians started setting fire to the village, I tried to talk to them. Tried to reason with them. Look what they've done to me.
I'll make them pay for this, I promise.
They burned my garden. Set everything on fire. I worked for years... planting it, caring for it, and now it's gone...
We'll plant a new one. You and I... together.
I wish I had your strength, Nerys. Your confidence. I'm so afraid.
Where's that damn medic?
Don't go. Stay with me. The medic can wait. I don't want to be alone.
The subject is asleep. I'm
It's a good start. Starfleet Intelligence will be very pleased.
There's more where that came from. Ghemor seems to know every bureaucrat and politician on Cardassia.
You look tired.
I've been up thirty hours straight.
You should get some rest.
Bashir to Major Kira.
Go ahead.
Please report to Ghemor's quarters immediately.
He's not responding to the hexadrin therapy anymore.
(calling out in the background) Nerys. Nerys.
I'm here.
(struggling to get out the words) Ask me questions, Nerys. We don't have much time.
You were talking about the Supreme Tribunal.
Yes... yes. The Tribunal. The Chief Archon tried to resist the Dominion takeover...
Status report.
A Jem'Hadar battleship is approaching the station.
Its weapons are armed and its targeting systems are active.
Red Alert. All crewmembers report to battle stations.
They're hailing us.
On screen.
Captain Sisko.
Gul Dukat. What's the meaning of this?
You said you'd take my request for Ghemor's extradition under advisement.
They've locked weapons on the station.
I eagerly await your decision.
Captain Sisko. Thank you for the kind invitation. This is one of my Dominion advisors... Weyoun.
We've met. But I saw you die.
That wasn't me. At least not exactly.
The Vorta are experts at cloning.
It tends to mitigate the risk involved in so much of our work. My predecessor was the fourth incarnation of our noble progenitor. I am the fifth.
Immortality.
Of a sort. Interested?
Dukat, you said you wanted to talk to me. Now's your chance.
I'll make it simple then. Tekeny Ghemor's not a well man... and he'd be better off under the care of his own people. We want him to know he can come home.
To attend his own execution?
Not at all. Ghemor's case has been reviewed by the new judicial system... and he's been cleared of any wrongdoing.
Dominion courts are renowned for their honesty and equanimity.
So, as you can see, there's no reason Ghemor can't return to Cardassia.
I don't think he would agree with you.
Perhaps we should find out.
Dukat, I have a week to live. Maybe less. Do you really expect me to trade my silence for a few short days under the Cardassian sun?
It's where you belong.
And it's where I'd be this very moment if you hadn't betrayed our people to the Dominion. Good day, Dukat.
He doesn't seem to like you very much. We are going to have to do something about your public image.
Gentlemen...
You haven't heard my entire offer. We have something else that I think might interest you. Your daughter, Iliana.
Iliana... I...
Don't listen to him.
Your daughter's alive. And I know where to find her.

I want to believe you, Dukat. But even if I did... Let's just say I don't like the company you're keeping. You and I might've come to an agreement, one Cardassian to another. But dealing with you now means dealing with them. And that makes the price too high.
You have your answer.
My ship will remain docked here for a few days...
In case you change your mind...
I won't.
What can I get for you, major? A frosty Bajoran ale perhaps? Or something stronger? How about a black hole?
Whatever.
You look terrible. Not that I mind. I like my women a little... rumpled.
Quark, just get me my drink.
I know just the thing. warm Enyak's milk. It'll help you sleep.
Come in.
Major. Sorry to disturb you.
Sorry enough to leave?
Your defense of Ghemor is admirable. But did it ever occur to you, you might be fighting the wrong battle? Do you recall the massacre at the Kiessa Monastery?
Kiessa? What's that got to do with Ghemor?
See for yourself. That is his official military record. You can verify everything on it with Bajoran Intelligence if you like.
You're enjoying this, aren't you? All these sick little games.
I have to admit, I get a certain perverse pleasure out of it. Read it or not. It's up to you.
I promise you, Dukat, I'm going to make you pay for this one day.
Maybe. But not today.
Nerys.
I'll be right there.
Now what?
I was... thirsty.
Just sit back...
You're all tangled up.
I'm sorry.
It's a little late for that, isn't it?
Nerys... is something wrong?
Yes, something's wrong. You lied to me.
About what?
About everything. But let's start with Kiessa Monestary.
Kiessa.
You were there, weren't you?
Dukat told you.
The Cardassian army burned Kiessa to the ground. Seventeen monks were killed.
They were hiding weapons for the Resistance. Weapons that were being used to kill my friends.

It was war. It was easy to despise you. But you weren't the monsters. We were. I wish I had never joined the military, never volunteered for duty on Bajor. But I did. And I can't change that, no matter how much I might want to.
So instead you hid the truth from me.
I didn't want you to hate me.
It's what you deserve.
Nerys!
Dabo! That is dabo, isn't it?
I don't see why you insist on playing this ridiculous game.
I like games.
Can I help you, captain?
I thought we could talk. I realize I haven't been much of a host.
Here. Have some Kanar.
No thank you. I'm not particularly thirsty right now.
I insist.
I never touch Kanar on an empty stomach. It's bad for the digestion.

In this case, that would be something of an understatement. There's enough voraxna poison in this bottle to kill a dozen Cardassians. It was delivered to Tekeny Ghemor not more than twenty minutes ago.
Fascinating.
What's wrong, Dukat? Afraid Ghemor might say something that could undermine your cozy new position?
Tread with care, Captain. You're coming dangerously close to accusing the head of the Cardassian government of attempted murder.
Is that what I'm doing?
How delightful. The mysterious plots, the subtle innuendos, the veiled threats. It's all so... entertaining.
My... that is quite toxic, isn't it?
Are you insane?
Vorta are immune to most forms of poison. It comes in handy when you're a diplomat.
Especially when you're working with the Cardassians.
You can keep the Kanar. Ghemor won't be drinking it.
Isn't it a little late for services?
I needed a quiet place to think.
If you have something to say to me, constable, say it.
I understand you've stopped visiting Ghemor.
He lied to me, Odo. I thought he was different. But he's just like the rest of them.

Is he really? I've seen his file, too, Major. He was nineteen when Kiessa was destroyed. He'd been in the military for less than a year. And he was only one of four hundred soldiers at the monestary. There's no way to know if he even fired a shot.
He shouldn't have been there at all.
This isn't about Ghemor's war record. If that really mattered, you wouldn't have waited for Dukat to hand it to you. You would've looked it up yourself.
What are you trying to say? That I should go back down there?
I wasn't saying that at all. Are you?
Father.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: Father. Hold still. You'll tear the bandages.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: My garden. They burned my garden.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: I know.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: I can hear the Prophets calling me. I can feel my pagh slipping away.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: Nerys.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: We found them. Cardassian Heavy Weapons Unit, Third Assault Group, Ninth Order.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: Hold on. I'll be right back.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: How far?
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: Just outside of Tempasa.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: I'll go with you.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: Are you sure?
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: I know the area.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: So does Gantt.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: They didn't shoot Gantt's father. They shot mine.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: We found the soldiers that did this to you. And I'm going to make them pay, just like I promised.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: The others... let them. You don't have to go.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: Yes, I do.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: I won't be long.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: Let's go.
scene: 55   INT. BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - TRIAGE AREA

quote: Come in.
I thought you should know... Ghemor's condition's deteriorated. He'll be dead within the hour.
Thank you for the information, Doctor.
That's it? "Thank you for the information?" Ghemor is dying.
Major, he wants to see you.
I don't want to see him.
Major, please... It's almost over. There's no more work to be done... no questions to ask. Just go to his quarters and sit with him.
I said no. Don't ask me again.
Fine. Do what you want. But you're making a mistake. Regardless of what Ghemor's done in the past, he doesn't deserve to die alone. No one does.
All four mortar rounds right in the central compound. And the way they ran... It was like kicking over a mound of barrowbugs.
scene: 60   EXT. OUTSIDE THE BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - DAY

quote: What was the count?
scene: 60   EXT. OUTSIDE THE BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - DAY

quote: Five skimmers destroyed. At least fifteen Cardassians dead. Not a bad day's work. We should celebrate.
scene: 60   EXT. OUTSIDE THE BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - DAY

quote: They kill us... we kill them. It's nothing worth celebrating.
scene: 60   EXT. OUTSIDE THE BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - DAY

quote: Nerys...
Your father.
He died calling your name.
Nerys...
Get another raiding party together. I want to hit those Cardassians again as soon as we have a chance.
Do you want me to get everyone together? Have Prylar Quen say a few words?
scene: 64   EXT. OUTSIDE THE BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - DAY

quote: There's nothing left to say.
scene: 64   EXT. OUTSIDE THE BAJORAN RESISTANCE BASE - DAY

quote: I didn't think you would come.
For a while there, neither did I.
... cause of death was CNS failure brought on by Yarim Fel Syndrome. One witness was present... Major Kira Nerys of the Bajoran Militia. The witness's statement is attached.
Major?
We're done here.
That's it? A quick postmortem, a statement from the witness, a little paperwork. It seems so... straightforward.
But it never is.

He got so quiet, toward the end. I could hear him whispering things... His wife's name... Iliana's... even mine. But then the pain got to be too much for him. He just... lay there... breathing. And every time he exhaled... there was a little pause. And I thought, "That's it. It's over." But then he'd force another breath. And another. I started counting them. One hundred... two hundred... three hundred... It was like he was fighting for every last second. I'm not even sure he knew I was there.
He knew. You gave him what he needed. He didn't die alone.
Maybe he gave me something I needed, too.

I missed my father's death by less than an hour... did you know that? Less than an hour. I always told myself that it was just bad luck... bad timing... the will of the Prophets. But the truth is... I didn't have to leave when I did. I could have stayed a while longer. But I saw a chance to get away, and I took it. I saw so much death during the Occupation... felt so much pain. But he was my father. My strength. And I couldn't stand watching that strength slip away.
So I ran.
Just like you tried to run from Ghemor.
He reminded me so much of my father. Going through it all again... I couldn't face it.
But in the end, you did. You were there for Ghemor.
I owed it to him. I owed it to my father to get it right this time.
You wanted to see me.
I understand Legate Ghemor has passed away.
You must be very relieved.
Captain, such cynicism doesn't suit you. All of Cardassia will mourn the passing of Tekeny Ghemor. He was a great man.
I'm surprised to hear you say that.
Not at all. It takes a great man to admit he was wrong. And that's what Ghemor did. You know... his last minute change of heart. His deathbed decision to embrace the new Dominion government.
Very moving. Except there's one small problem. It never happened.
As you said... it's a small problem.
I'd like the body transferred to my ship. We'll take him home and bury him with full state honors.
I'm afraid that's impossible. Legate Ghemor's funeral arrangements have already been taken care of.
Cadet.
Continuing to emit distress signals on all frequencies, sir.
Chief.
We're still venting plasma. Any ship passing within a hundred million kilometers will know we're here -- -- and that we're not going anywhere.
In other words, we're sitting ducks.
Looks that way.
We have company, Captain. Two Dominion ships heading this way, bearing one-nine-seven mark one- three-five.
They'll have us in weapons range in twenty-two seconds.
Shields?
Shields at thirty percent.
Phaser banks?
The entire weapons array is off-line.
What do we do now, captain?
Now we find something to hold onto.
Shields are down to twenty percent.
I don't know how much more of this we can take.
Steady, people.
Now?
Now. Shields up. Engines at full impulse. Power to main phasers.
Target locked.
Fire.
Cadet, any more Dominion ships out there?
None that I can see.
This is the captain speaking. All hands, stand down. Good job, people.
We're being hailed by the Rotarran. Commander Worf would like to speak to you.
Onscreen.
My hero.
Well done, captain. You were a very effective decoy.
How about next time we switch roles? That way, I can rescue you.
You may have to wait awhile, captain. We've just received orders from Starfleet Command. All ships in this sector are to fall back to Starbase Three-Seven- Five.
Fall back again?
Engage and retreat. Engage and retreat. I'm telling you, that's become our favorite tune.
Well, we'd better learn a new one or the next song we'll be singing is "Hail the Conquering Dominion."
I wouldn't start learning those lyrics just yet, Doctor. Worf, we'll see you at Starbase Three-Seven-Five.
I'll be waiting.
(snapping an order to helm) Set a course for these coordinates. Warp seven.
I don't know what all you brass hats in Starfleet Command are thinking, but take it from a simple field officer, we're not going to win this war by running away from the enemy.
Benjamin -- troop morale is at an all-time low. Even the Klingons are starting to wonder if we can defeat the Dominion. We need a victory -- a big victory. And we need it soon!
I couldn't agree with you more.
(pounding her fist on his desk) Then do something about it.
I have.
In fact, I'm presenting a plan to Starfleet Command at oh-eight- hundred, tomorrow.
What plan?
We're going to retake Deep Space Nine.
Everything seems to be perfectly normal. I'm sorry, Garak.
Keep looking, Doctor. I'm sure whatever Starfleet put in there is very well hidden.
Ridiculous.
That's easy for you to say, Chief. You don't know them as well as I do. They're desperate people.
Garak, you're not going to get any of us to believe that Starfleet Intelligence has implanted some kind of neural transponder in your brain to monitor your thoughts.
I would've if I were them. In fact, when I was conducting interrogations for the Obsidian Order, I did a lot worse.
They're not interrogating you, Mister Garak, they're debriefing you. There is a difference.
Not from where I'm sitting.
Tarkalean tea.
I'll take a raktajino, Julian.
And a raktajino.

Look, Garak -- we're at war with the Dominion. Cardassia is part of the Dominion. You're a Cardassian. And at one time, a fairly important one. Of course Starfleet Intelligence is going to press you for specifics -- they need to know everything you know.
The smallest detail could prove extremely important.
Well take it from me, it's a lot more fun asking questions than answering them. All things considered, I'd prefer being on the Defiant with all of you.
Believe me, you haven't been missing much.
Hopefully, that's about to change.
You think Starfleet Command will approve Sisko's plan?
We'll find out soon enough. He's presenting it now.
Here's to retaking the castle.
And planting our flag on its battlements, once again.
You two spent too much time in the holosuites...

By putting together a task force comprised of elements from the Second, Fifth and Ninth fleets, I believe that we can take back Deep Space Nine -- the most important piece of real estate in the quadrant.
Your plan, Captain Sisko, is not without merit. However, I remain skeptical. The Dominion will undoubtedly send a large fleet to stop you.
Which will divert their forces and slow their advance into Federation territory.
As well as leave their flank vulnerable.
Giving us a chance to go on the offensive, for a change.
There's one thing that still concerns me...
What's that, Admiral?
Earth. You've left it a very tempting target.
Earth would still be defended by the Third Fleet.
But what if you're wrong and the Dominion doesn't commit its forces to protect Deep Space Nine? What if they launch a full-scale assault on Earth instead?
If we do what you're proposing, we'll never get reinforcements there in time.
The Dominion won't attack Earth.
How can you be sure?
Because Earth isn't the key to the Alpha Quadrant. The wormhole is. And whoever controls Deep Space Nine controls the wormhole.
Unbelievable. Amazing. What nerve.
Morn -- you do have a problem.
But lucky for you, the solution is simple. You're a grown man. If you don't want to attend your mother's birthday party, you don't have to.
And if she keeps whining about it, just remind her there's a war on and you have things to do. Another ale?
Here. It's on the house.
Major, you ready?
(not thrilled at the prospect) Now?
Right now.
All right, but I don't think it'll do any good.
I keep telling myself that Odo never meant for Rom to get arrested... that it was all a mistake. Bad timing. Bad luck.
That's what I thought, too -- at first.
I've known Odo a long time... he's not a collaborator.
Then why's your brother still in a holding cell?
We're here to see Odo.
scene: 20   INT. ANOTHER HABITAT RING CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS

quote: The Founders are not to be disturbed.
scene: 20   INT. ANOTHER HABITAT RING CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS

quote: Odo will make an exception for us.
scene: 20   INT. ANOTHER HABITAT RING CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS

quote: There are no exceptions.
scene: 20   INT. ANOTHER HABITAT RING CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS

quote: I'd like to hear that from Odo.
scene: 20   INT. ANOTHER HABITAT RING CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS

quote: I'm sorry, major, but you're wasting your time. His orders were quite clear. He doesn't want to see anyone. Not until his guest leaves.
scene: 20   INT. ANOTHER HABITAT RING CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS

quote: And how long has his "guest" been visiting?
scene: 20   INT. ANOTHER HABITAT RING CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS

quote: As far as I know, the female changeling hasn't left his quarters for three days.
scene: 20   INT. ANOTHER HABITAT RING CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS

quote: Step away from the door, Ferengi.
scene: 20   INT. ANOTHER HABITAT RING CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS

quote: Hey, hey...
scene: 20   INT. ANOTHER HABITAT RING CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS

quote: Perhaps it would be best if you left. My... colleague over here takes his duties very seriously. I promise to tell Odo you were here.
scene: 20   INT. ANOTHER HABITAT RING CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS

quote: Let's go, Quark.
scene: 20   INT. ANOTHER HABITAT RING CORRIDOR - CONTINUOUS

quote: So that is how Solids experience intimacy.
Not all Solids. Humans, Bajorans...
I really must thank you, Odo.
For what?
For giving me a new insight into the Solids.
And what have you learned?
That what they consider intimacy is only a shadow of what we experience in the Great Link. You don't agree?
I didn't say that.
You've done this before.
Not often.
But when you have, you enjoyed it.
Yes.
And you regret not having experienced it with Major Kira.
I'd rather not discuss Major Kira.
I don't see why not. When we link, your feelings for her are made very clear.
Then why do you insist we "talk" about it?
Because talking is still important to you. But I promise you, one day it won't be. One day, the Link will be all you need. And that day is coming soon.
Is it?
It's amazing you've survived this long without it. It's only now, after I've been away from the Great Link myself, that I understand how painful it must have been for you.
It hasn't always been easy.
Well, you never have to be alone again.
I should be going. There's a meeting of the station's Ruling Council. Dukat and Weyoun are expecting me.
That meeting was held three days ago.
Three days? How could I have lost track of that much time?
Does that bother you?
Yes, it does...

Don't let it. You've been living with the Solids' concept of time for too long. Let them worry about meetings, schedules, obligations... ... none of that has anything to do with you. You're a changeling. You're timeless.
As am I.
You asked to see me, major?
That's right.
First, tell me something. What do you think of this?
It's one of Ziyal's paintings.
I know who the artist is. Her father gave it to me. He claims that it won some sort of prize on Cardassia.
Gul Dukat must be very proud.
I suppose. Is it any good?
I think so. Why -- don't you?
I don't know how to judge it. You see, my people lack a sense of aesthetics.
That's too bad.
I sometimes think so as well. But if aesthetics were truly important, the Founders would've included it in our genetic makeup.
Or they made a mistake.
Gods don't make mistakes. Though sometimes I think it would be nice to be able to carry a tune. So, what can I do for you, Major?
It's about Rom.
Ah, yes, the Ferengi saboteur.
He's been in a holding cell for over a week.
Has it really been that long?
I was hoping you would consider releasing him.
Impossible. You can't release a man and then execute him. It makes no sense.
Execute Rom?

He committed an act of terrorism against the Dominion. Not only did he try to interfere with our efforts to bring down the minefield, but as I understand it, he was also the diabolical genius who came up with the idea of self-replicating mines in the first place. I'm afraid there's no getting around it, Major. He must be made an example so that others think twice before they act against us.
Rom's married to a Bajoran citizen...

I'm well aware of that. And I'm willing to believe -- for now -- that his wife isn't a co-conspirator. Otherwise, treaty or no treaty, she would share his fate. I'm sorry, major, but the Dominion takes a dim view of terrorism. Your friend must pay the price for his crime.
We'll see what the Bajoran government says about that.
I'm afraid their pleas will fall on deaf ears.
Major.
Would this be more aesthetically pleasing if it were blue?
I'm going to die.
Stop saying that.
I didn't say it -- -- he did.
What I said is that they're planning to execute you -- it's not the same thing.
It is to me.
Rom -- we are not going to let them hurt you. Kira has gone to the Bajoran Council of Ministers. She's asking them to lodge an official protest.
That's sweet. But I doubt it'll do any good.
I don't think Weyoun cares much for latinum. I'm a dead man.
Would you please stop upsetting Leeta?
Sorry.
Besides, you think your big brother is going to let anything happen to you?
What can you do?
I'm not sure. But I'll think of something. No matter what it takes... no matter what I have to do... I'm going to get you out of here.
Oh, Quark -- you do that and I'll work your dabo tables for free.
For how long?
An entire year.
Make it two.
Brother!
Isn't your life worth two years? Now sit tight and trust your older brother.
But I don't want you to try to save me.
What are you talking about? They must've done something to his mind.
What mind?
I'm serious. Brother, you have more important things to worry about.
The bar's doing fine. But thanks for caring.
I'm not talking about the bar.
Rom -- what could be more important than your life?

Destroying the anti-graviton beam to prevent the Dominion from taking down the minefield. You've got to finish what I started. The fate of the entire Alpha Quadrant rests in your hands. Billions and billions of people are counting on you.
Boy, are they going to be disappointed.
Brother, you can do this. You have to do this. You will do this.
What happens if I get caught?
Then we'll die together. Side-by- side, heads held high -- knowing we did our best.
Oh, Rom...
But I don't want to die...
(still a man with a mission) If that's what's written, then that's what's written. Now get going, brother. You have a lot of work to do.
So, tell me, Leeta... what else is new? Have they fixed the sonic shower in our quarters yet?
Ziyal.
Nerys -- I haven't seen you in weeks.
Do you have a minute?
Sit down.
I need you to talk to your father for me.
About what?
Rom.
Father, I need to talk to you.
Is something wrong, my dear?
Nothing that you can't fix.
(pleased he can help his daughter) Name it.
I want you to free Rom.
You're joking.
Not at all.
I can't free Rom. He's been sentenced to death by the Dominion.
You can pardon him. Don't you see, Father, this is your chance to show the Bajoran people -- to show Major Kira who you really are. A forgiving, compassionate man -- a great man.
Tell me, Ziyal, were you involved -- in any way -- with the plan to sabotage the station?
(pulling her hands away; angry) No, I wasn't involved!
You're sure of that? I can't help you unless you tell me the truth.
I am telling you the truth! The question is have you been telling me the truth.
About what?
That the Bajorans are wrong about you. That you regret the horrible things you had to do during the occupation.
I do regret them. Deeply.
Then this is your chance to prove it to everyone, including me. Show us that you're capable of mercy.
Rom is an enemy of the state. And enemies of the state don't deserve mercy.
Spoken like a true Cardassian.
I am a Cardassian. And so are you.
No... I'm not. I could never be like you.
Nausicaans? You can't trust them.

I trust latinum. And so do they. Five bars will buy me five Nausicaans, a fast ship and very few questions. Breaking Rom out of the holding cell will be child's play compared to the things they're used to doing.

Forget it, Quark. Freeing Rom is going to take careful, precise planning. That's not the Nausicaan way -- they're thugs. They'll come strutting onto the station, look at a Jem'Hadar the wrong way and the next thing you know there'll be blood on the Promenade.
You think I can get my money back?
Major, a freighter loaded with Tammeron grain is due to arrive within the hour. See to it that Cargo Bay Five is ready to receive it.
I'll take care of it.
Yes, you will. Now.
That attitude of yours, major... it won't be tolerated forever.
You don't like my attitude, Damar? You're welcome to try and change it.
I don't understand what Dukat sees in that woman.
Then you need to get your eyes examined.
One kanar. Want me to leave the bottle?
Maybe I should have you taste it first. Make sure it isn't poisoned.
Poisoning customers is bad for business.
True. But some people might place a brother's revenge above business.
Not this Ferengi.
You're a credit to your race, Quark. Unlike your brother, you've chosen to back the winning side.
All right, are you going to tell me or do you want me to guess?
Tell you what?
Don't be coy with me. Either someone you don't like has died or your promotion came through.
It's better than that.
It's about the minefield.
What about it?
It's coming down.
I've heard that before.
Remember those field tests I was telling you about? They were successful. We've begun to deactivate the mines.
Well, you've got your work cut out for you. What's it going to take -- a couple of months? A year?
(no longer hiding anything) A week?
That's right, one week and the Alpha Quadrant will be ours.
Gentlemen, this mission cannot succeed without the involvement of the Klingon Defense Forces.
We agree, Captain. But Chancellor Gowron does not.
Then you have to change his mind.
The Chancellor is reluctant to commit such a large fleet to a single engagement.
He feels it would leave the Empire vulnerable.
Starfleet Command had the same concerns about Earth. But after careful consideration, they decided it was worth the risk.
General, perhaps you should return to Kronos and make your plea in person. The Chancellor has great respect for you. If you cannot persuade him, no one can.
I will go see Gowron -- -- and you will come with me.
The chancellor no longer considers me a friend.
I know. But what could be better -- an ally and an enemy, both telling him the same thing? He'll have no choice but to agree.
Gentlemen, I need those ships.
And you shall have them.
A week? You're sure about that?
That's what he said. And believe me, this was no idle boast.
We've got to stop them.
And end up sharing a cell with my brother? No, thanks. If we could only get to Odo... make him see what's going on. He'd have to help us...
Forget about Odo. First, we can't get to him, and second, he wouldn't help us even if we did.
Then what we have to do is warn Starfleet.
And how do you suggest we get a message out to them?
You're asking me? You're the terrorist, I'm just a bartender.
From the look on your faces I can see you haven't had much luck getting Rom out of jail.
And the news just keeps getting worse.
It's not all bad.
Trust us, Jake. It is.
Not for me. I'm getting a message out to my Dad.
How?
I'm a reporter. I have my ways.
Jake -- this is no time for games.
Morn?
He's going home for his mother's birthday or something. He has an encrypted message for my Dad in one of her presents.
Are you sure this is reliable?
I've known the courier for five years. I trust him.
Then we have a problem. According to this, the minefield's coming down in three days. The Ninth Fleet won't be here for at least four.
Then I suggest we go without them.
What about the Klingons?
Looks like we go without them, too. We've run out of time, Admiral.
If those Dominion reinforcements come through the wormhole... we'll have lost everything.
We take the ships we have, fight our way to Deep Space Nine, and destroy that anti-graviton emitter. It's our only hope.
Do it.
There.
Where?
Over there. That flash of light was the anti-graviton beam hitting a mine.
And disabling its replication unit...
Exactly. Didn't you see it?
I'm afraid not.
For months you've been demanding that I take down those mines and now that it's finally happening, you can't even see it?
Weak eyes.
Excuse me?
My people have poor eyesight. It's something we've learned to live with. The Jem'Hadar, on the other hand, have excellent vision. I suppose they need it more than we do.
There's another one!
I'll have to take your word for it.
Once we've disabled the replication units in all the mines, we can detonate the entire minefield. And I guarantee, weak eyes or not, that explosion you'll see.
When will you be ready to proceed?
Approximately seventy-eight hours. Three more days and we can start bringing Jem'Hadar reinforcements through the wormhole.
Excellent. I knew you could do it, Dukat.
Did you?
(with absolute "Weyoun" sincerity) I never doubted you for a moment.
Sir, I have new information on enemy fleet movements.
Go ahead.
The Second Fleet has fallen back past the Kotanka System, while the Fifth Fleet has pulled out of the fighting along the Vulcan border.
Both fleets have converged here --
-- at Starbase Three-Seven-Five.
Isn't that where Captain Sisko is stationed?
He's been made an adjutant to Admiral Ross.
Good for him. Now why have those fleets gathered there?
I'm not sure.
You're not sure? Two large enemy fleets break off from the front lines to rendezvous at a starbase and you have no idea why?
We'll have to find out, won't we?
See that you do.
He should speak to you with greater respect.
One day, I'll let you teach him that lesson.
But right now, there's something more pressing I need you to do. It's of a personal nature -- a matter of some delicacy. It's about my daughter.
Ziyal?
We've had a misunderstanding. I want you to go and convince her to speak with me.
Sir -- I really think I could be more valuable tracking that enemy fleet.
I've given you an order, Damar. We're on the verge of a great victory and when it comes, I want my daughter by my side. Is that understood?
I really believed that my father had changed... that he wanted to be a man of peace.
I think he believes that, too. When it suits his purpose.
Everything he's ever said to me has been a lie...
Not everything. He really does care for you.
I don't care. I'm not going back to him.
You don't believe me, do you?
Right now, you're angry and disappointed. But that'll pass. And then you'll have to decide what to do.
Ziyal, I need to speak to you.
You and I have nothing to talk about.
Maybe not. But you and your father do. He wants to see you.
Well I don't want to see him.
You heard her.

Stay out of this, major. Listen to me, Ziyal. Your father is a great man. A man of destiny. But he also carries great burdens. He knows our alliance with the Dominion is a dangerous one. If we show any sign of weakness, our allies will turn on us. That's why we must all help your father remain strong. So I ask you to be a true daughter of Cardassia and stand beside him.
It should be obvious even to you, Damar, that I am not a "true daughter of Cardassia."
What's obvious to me is that your father should've left you to rot in that Breen prison camp. But he didn't. He took pity on you and it's your duty to repay him.
Now come with me.
Leave her alone.
And if I don't? What happens then?
Did you kill him?
No, but I thought about it.
What are you going to do when he wakes up?
That's up to him.
I thought I'd stop by and wish you luck.
Thanks. My father says you can never have too much luck.
Your father sounds like a wise man.
And he makes a good jambalaya.
What's this?
It's the Bajoran Ancient Texts.
The Emissary looks for guidance on the eve of battle?
Guidance, insights... loopholes. I'll take anything I can get.
And what do the Prophets tell you?
Maybe when this war's over you'll get the chance to study them closer.
It would be a welcome change.
Chief, I was just coming to see you. Can you believe it? They made me an ensign.
I didn't realize that things were going so bad.
Scary, isn't it?
If my classmates at the Academy could only see me now...
They'd be surprised, would they?
Amazed is more like it.
What do they know.
Anyway, I just wanted to say thanks for all your help.
My help?
I've learned a lot from you -- and not just about engineering. You've shown me what it takes to be a good soldier.
Well don't let that uniform go to your head. You've got a lot to learn yet.
And you will.
Congratulations, ensign. Wear it with pride.
I intend to, Chief.
Captain on the bridge.
I've kept it warm for you, Ben.
Ensign, alert all ships. we're moving out.
Aye, sir.
Our initial intelligence reports have been verified. The Federation fleet is on the move.
Do we know their destination?
It would appear they're headed here.
Here?
He knows we're taking down the minefield. Someone must've gotten a message out.
So it would seem.
No matter. We'll crush them.
Yes, we will. And in order to do that, we're going to have to pull a significant number of our ships off the front lines.
Do it.
Once the minefield comes down, there'll be more than enough ships to take their place.
(nodding impatiently to Weyoun) I understand. One moment.
I want your permission to arrest Major Kira.
Kira? What about Ziyal -- did you talk to her?
She doesn't want to see you. When I insisted, the major... objected.
What did you do to Ziyal?
I did nothing to her.
Then why did Kira attack you? You must've done something... threatened my daughter in some way. I told you to be tactful.
Excuse me, but don't you think resolving family squabbles can wait until after we've won this war? Weak eyes, good ears.
Yes, of course. You're quite right.
Then you're clear on what must be done.
We will call back enough ships to destroy the Federation fleet and hold this station.
The Federation is moving against us?
That's right. Now I want to hear exactly what went on between you and Ziyal.
Odd. I've stood here countless times... yet somehow everything looks different.
It's the Solids. They look small, don't they? Insignificant.
It's not their fault.
I'm not placing blame.
They're trapped.
Confined to a single shape.
A single perspective.
It's so limiting.
I feel sorry for them.
They need our guidance, Odo. Not our pity.
They cherish their freedom.
We'll have to break them of that.
Break them?
In a manner of speaking. This language of the Solids... it's so imprecise.
What exactly do you plan to do?
The Solids are no longer your concern, Odo. What must be done, will be done. It's as simple as that.
Forgive me for intruding but I have important news about the war.
Why don't you return to your quarters, Odo. I'll join you there shortly.
Everything will be fine. I promise.
I must say, you're doing a wonderful job with Odo.
Meaning what?
Meaning that he's always posed a potential threat to our plans. But you seem to have... neutralized him quite nicely.
Neutralize Odo? Is that why you think I'm here? Odo is a changeling. Bringing him home -- returning him to the Great Link means more to us than the Alpha Quadrant itself. Is that clear?
I meant no disrespect...
Of course you didn't. You are what you are... a loyal subject of the Dominion. Come, walk with me. You said you had important news...
Major!
Kira.
Wait, please.
I have nothing to say to you.
I understand that you're angry.
You bet I'm angry.
Do you have any idea what's been going on?
Yes... somewhat... I've been occupied.
Dukat's bringing down the minefield, the Federation is about to be overrun by Dominion reinforcements, and Weyoun's ordered Rom's execution. And you've been... occupied.
It's so difficult to explain...
If you're going to tell me about the Link, don't bother. I'm a Solid, remember. I wouldn't understand.
Nerys...
I'm sorry.
Sorry? That's what you wanted to say to me? You're sorry?
Yes.
Let me tell you something, Odo.
We are way past "sorry."
Sir, incoming message from the Cortez. They're still having trouble stabilizing the guidance thrusters on their port nacelle.
Tell them to drop back and make repairs. Bring up the Sarek to take its place.
Will do.
That's the eleventh ship to fall out of formation.
Nice of you to keep track, Garak.
He can't help being negative -- it's his nature.
On the contrary, I always hope for the best. Unfortunately, experience has taught me to expect the worst.
I'm picking something up... (a beat as he reads his console) Sir, it's a large Dominion fleet, bearing zero-zero-four mark zero- zero-nine.
How large?
Twelve hundred and fifty four ships.
They outnumber us two to one.
Now who's being negative.
Onscreen. Maximum magnification.
To all ships, this is Captain Sisko. Assume attack formation Delta-two.
There's an old saying, "Fortune favors the bold." Well, we're about to find out.
Doctor?

quote: So... I guess we're going.

quote: Looks that way.

quote: Tell me about this... house we're going to.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: It's a gorgeous two-hundred-year- old cottage filled with antiques sitting in the middle of a deep, dark forest. It has three fireplaces... two balconies...
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: I see...
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: And it's twenty kilometers to the nearest neighbor... thirty to the nearest town.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Why am I not surprised?
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Of what?
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: The Holana river. You can see it from every room in the house. And at night... when the stars are out and all you can hear is the rushing water... it may be one of the most romantic spots on all of Bajor.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: That's it! I don't care what Keiko says, I'm not going. You go. I'll wait an hour and then tell Keiko that... you left without me... that there was a miscommunication about the time you were leaving.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Think she'll buy it?
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: She'll probably accuse us of having another fight and behaving like children, but I can handle that. The important thing is to make sure that we don't get anywhere near that... that place together.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: You're absolutely right. In fact, I'll go to the capital and see Shakaar.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: That's the best idea you've had all week.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Have a good trip.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Thanks.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: It would've been nice...
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: In another life.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Let's not even think about that.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Forget I brought it up.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Miles... ?
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Yes, Nerys?
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Get out.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Right.

quote: Compound fracture of the left radius... two fractured ribs... torn ligaments... strained tendons... numerous bruises, contusions, and scratches. What have you been doing?
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: You mean, what have we been doing?
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Never mind. I don't need that particular image running around in my head. I'll just... treat you.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: What happened to you two?
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: We...
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Well... if you must know...
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: No. No. I don't need that image either. In fact, I'm going to stop asking that question altogether. People come in and I'll treat them, that's all. Have a seat in the Surgery. I'll... be with you in a minute.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: You realize that... according to Klingon tradition...
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: According to tradition, we have to get married.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: But as you keep insisting, you are not a traditional woman.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: And the truth is, Worf... at heart, you're not much of a traditional man.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: You may be right... How... do you wish to proceed?
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: I don't know.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: You must have some idea. You were the...
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Yes. And now there are many questions that must be answered.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: I don't feel like answering questions. Why don't we just take it one day at a time and see what happens.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: I do not like the... uncertainty of that arrangement.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Well, one thing's for certain... You've stopped thinking about Grilka.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Is he... laughing?
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: I didn't think he knew how.

quote: I will take my leave now, Quark. Thank you for your... financial advice.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: My pleasure. I hope it was worth the trip.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: The trip... had its own rewards.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: I'll be back.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Don't come back too soon. I need time to heal.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: There're days I really hate this job.
episode: Looking For par'Mach in All the Wrong Places

quote: Computer... Time.
Eighteen twenty-one hours.
Can I help you?
I think so.
Where is it?
Where is what? I don't even know what you're looking for...
Yes, you do. Well?
It's not here.
That's not good.
Is it possible we've got the wrong man?
It's starting to look that way.
This is very embarrassing.
Listen to me. We know why you're here, we know who you came to meet, and we know what you were going to give her. So for the last time, where is it?
All right... I'll take you to it.
See, it was him all along.
I thought it was on stun.
Look what you did to the carpet.
What do we do now? We don't have time to search the whole station.
We wait for the woman. She might know where he hid it...
You wanted to see us?
Is that the new holosuite program?
The next chapter in the continuing adventures of Julian Bashir, Secret Agent. It came in this morning.
Finally. That friend of yours promised to send it two months ago.
According to Felix, it's worth the wait. He said it's the most elaborate program he's ever designed.
What parts do we get to play?
You, Jadzia, will be Lady Wantsomore, a beautiful socialite who's been brainwashed to assassinate the Queen of England.
Somebody stop me.
What about me?
Odo plays Nigel Dunlap, a former agent who comes out of retirement to help me foil this diabolical plot.
Perfect.
I play --
We know who you play, Julian. What about me?
You're Falcon, of course.
Falcon? Again? I'm tired of being the bad guy.
But you're so good at it.
So... is Saturday all right for everyone?
Fine.
No problem.
Odo?
What do I have to do again?
Save the Queen.
Not only that, you get to drive a fancy automobile, go to posh parties... -- and steal her away from Falcon.
He steals my girl?
Maybe you should find another Nigel Dunlap.
Are you kidding? Look at her.
I'm busy on Saturday.
We'll do it when you're not busy.
I don't think so. I'm sorry. I should never have agreed to be a part of this in the first place.
I guess we'll have to find someone else to play Odo's part.
I'll do it.
Look, I already told you --
I don't want to play dabo, I don't want a holosuite, and I don't want anything to eat.
Can I interest you in my collection of Risean tapestries?
Why don't you leave her alone, Quark? Can't you see she's not interested?
How do I know she's not interested unless I ask?
Maybe you should spend less time bothering your customers, and more time keeping an eye on your business.
Don't worry, I can keep my eyes on more than one thing at a time.
Really? What about him?
He's got a graviton emitter hidden in his ring -- he's manipulating the table for his friend over there.
You're very observant.
Thanks.
Are you waiting for someone?
You. Where have you been all my life?
Pardon me?
Isn't that what you were hoping I'd say?
It's just... you keep glancing at the door.
I'm waiting for someone.
That's all I meant.
Sorry. I thought you had other things on your mind. Must be those bedroom eyes of yours.
Bedroom eyes... ?
You probably get that all the time.
Not really.
If anyone bothers you again let me know. I'm Security Chief Odo. My office is just across the Promenade.
I'll be all right.
Well. I have to go. To work. In my office.
Across the Promenade.
Exactly.
Look at this.
I went to check the contents of that crate -- a tentacle grabbed hold of my hand.
Gagh. The Klingons have been getting regular shipments since the day they were posted here.
I can't believe they eat that stuff.
What are you doing?
Nothing.
What are you looking at?
Well, actually I -- I'm... nevermind.
What?
It's embarrassing.
Just tell me.
Last night, a woman in Quark's told me I have... bedroom eyes.
I'm trying to see if it's true.
Tell me about this woman...
She thought I was... trying to seduce her. It was all just a misunderstanding.
If you say so. Are you going to see her again?
I have no idea. Why?
She's obviously very perceptive.
Meaning what?
Meaning you should see her again.
She came in this morning as soon as I opened, stayed for about an hour and left.
Who?
That woman you were making eyes at last night.
I wasn't making eyes at her.
Un-huh. Why do you always fall for the same type?
What are you talking about?
The tough, no nonsense type -- like a certain Bajoran major?
Hello, again.
What's this all about?
You tried to break into the station's computer. Why?
My friend never showed up last night. I wanted to check the passenger manifests to find out if he came aboard.
Why didn't you come to me? I could've checked the manifests for you.
When you grow up on Finnea Prime, you learn not to trust policemen.
Dataport bothering you?
The security protocols protecting your computer generated some nasty feedback.
I know. I designed them that way.
Nice job. I couldn't stay interfaced long enough to break past the encryption lockouts.
That was the idea. Tell me... Arissa, what's a nice woman like you doing with a dataport?
They're not illegal.
They ought to be. People tend to use them to access information other people don't want them to access.
I've heard that.
This Idanian you were waiting for in Quark's... Tauvid Rem. What were you meeting him about?
A personal matter.
I suppose I could just go to his quarters and ask him.
I'd rather you didn't. It's a delicate situation.
I'm listening.
Tauvid's well known for... ... finding people. People who don't necessarily want to be found. He's helping me locate my daughter. I gave her up when she was born, fifteen years ago.
I see.
He told me he had information about her. That's all I know. I've been looking for her a long time. Please, let me talk to him.
All right. I'll take you to him. We'll sort the rest out later.
Thank you.
Maybe he's not in.
According to the access log, he's inside.
This is Security. Hello?
He's not here.
Oh, yes he is -- what's left of him.
The residue we found contained Idanian DNA. I think it's reasonable to assume it came from Tauvid Rem. Do you have any idea why someone would want to kill him?
No. But considering what he does for a living, he probably had dealings with all sorts of marginal characters. Maybe it was a robbery.
What makes you say that?
I didn't see any personal belongings in his quarters. Did your deputies find anything?
No.
Whatever happened, I doubt it had anything to do with me or my daughter.
That depends. It's possible that someone doesn't want you to find your daughter.
Tauvid didn't give me any indication of that when we spoke.
When was that?
About three days ago.
I can't believe this... I was so close to finding her. Now I'm going to have to start all over again. If you'll let me...
In case you'd forgotten, I'm facing charges for trying to break into your computer.
Considering the fact you weren't able to access any secured information, I've decided to drop those charges.
I appreciate that very much.
You're free to go.
Thank you. You're a very kind man.
I hope you find your daughter.
Morn! We're closed.
Go home.
I'm afraid the Assay Office is closed for the evening.
If you want to secure any valuables, you'll have to come back in the morning.
Thanks, I'll do that.
I didn't realize I'd tripped an alarm.
You didn't. You're good.
I still got caught.
I've been following you.
I didn't know.
I'm good, too. So, did you find anything in Tauvid's locker?
Would you believe me if I said no?
Actually, I'd have you strip- searched.
That might be fun... but in the interest of saving time...
I've never seen a data crystal quite like this. It looks like there's a phase inverter embedded inside. It's not going to be easy to decode.
Given that all it contains is information about a missing girl, Tauvid went to great lengths to secure it.
You know how Idanians are... they're a secretive race.
You realize that it would be a simple matter for me to have a Doctor examine you to determine if you've ever been pregnant?
You keep threatening to have me stripped down and examined. I'm trying not to read too much into that.
You don't have a daughter, do you?
No.
That's probably the first true statement I've heard you make.
Not quite. I meant what I said about your eyes.
What's on the crystal?
I don't know. But I need to find out.
Why?
Because if I don't... I'm dead.
Maybe you'd better start at the beginning.
I work for a man named Draim. I see you've heard of him.
He's with the Orion Syndicate. If I'm not mistaken, he specializes in blackmail and extortion. Where do you fit into his organization?
I access computer systems and steal information for him... government data, business plans -- whatever he asks for.
I hope you're well paid. That's a dangerous line of work. Trigger the wrong security protocol and you could end up with permanent brain damage.
I think about that from time to time. But then there's not much I can do about it. You don't quit the Orion Syndicate unless they say you can.
Do you want to quit?
That's why I came to meet Tauvid.
Who was he?
I don't know.
Then why did you come meet him?
He told me he had information... information I could use to break away from Draim, free and clear.
What made you believe he was telling the truth?
I don't know. I just did. I'm not even sure how he knew I wanted to get out.
Did he tell you what this information was?
No. But for some reason I decided to trust him. I know it sounds insane, but I guess I was desperate.
Did you tell anyone you were coming here?
No. Draim must've monitored my communications. How else could he have gotten his people here before I arrived.
You think Draim had Tauvid killed to keep you from getting this datacrystal?
And whoever he hired to do it is probably still on the station. You can be sure Draim wants to know what's on that crystal as much as I do.
What are you smiling about?
I'm just picturing myself trying to explain all this to the authorities back on Finnea. Not that they'll listen. They'll just send me to prison.
I'm not turning this over to the Finneans.
You're not?

I'm placing you in protective custody while I have someone try to access the crystal; in the meantime, I want you to have a look at the security recordings made at the airlocks. Draim was probably careful to send someone you wouldn't recognize, but you never know.
Why are you doing this?
Doing what?
Helping me.
Why not?
You mean... you're just doing it out of the goodness of your heart?
I don't have a heart.
Could've fooled me.
What'd you get?
It's called hasperat.
Where is she?
She's with that changeling security chief.
Spicy...
They have the crystal.
We've got to make sure she doesn't access it.
She's pretty. I was hoping we wouldn't have to kill her.
You'll get over it.
My mouth's on fire -- Did you bring something to drink?
My hands were full...
Nice room.
Don't get too used to it. You're not staying here. Odo to Security, begin transport.
There. Now, if anyone was watching, they'll think you're still in the other quarters.
Nice trick. I hope it works.
Interesting furniture...
I use these things to practice shape-shifting.
These are your quarters?
I thought this'd be the last place anyone would look for you.
I could use the company.
I have two deputies stationed outside in the corridor. They're posing as a maintenance crew doing repairs.
Where are you going to sleep?
I don't need a bed. I regenerate by reverting to a gelatinous state...
Sounds relaxing.
It is, actually.
I'm so tired I wouldn't mind being in a gelatinous state myself.
I understand you weren't able to identify anyone from the security recordings.
No.
I haven't had much luck identifying Tauvid either. It's not even his real name. He took three different transports to get to the station, and used a different identity each time.
I transmitted his picture to the Idanian Authorities. I'm not sure if we'll get a reply...
... as you said before, they're a secretive race.
What about the crystal?
Dax and Chief O'Brien are still trying to get past the encryption lockouts.
Maybe I should try to interface with it?
That's not a good idea. The first time they attempted to access it, the feedback shorted out the computer. I'd hate to see what it would do to your dataport.
I can't believe what I've gotten myself into... walking out on Draim to meet someone I don't even know -- I must've lost my mind.
You said you were desperate.
Why do you think I got involved with Draim in the first place?
I know life on Finnea isn't easy, but you must've had other options.
Have you ever been there?
It's not like a Federation world where everything is handed to you.
You know how I ended up with this? I was a net-girl. I told myself I wasn't selling my body since there was no actual contact. But I was. I let men into my mind for money.

Draim was one of them. That's how we met. Before I knew it, I was working for him. He paid me more than I'd ever seen before. I was so far removed from the consequences of what I was doing, it was easy to pretend I wasn't hurting anyone. I'd hear things now and then. Some businessman Draim had me investigate would disappear. I'd try to convince myself it had nothing to do with me. But after while... I couldn't pretend anymore. I wanted out.
I guess I'm finally going to get my wish. Only problem is, I'll be dead. Why am I crying... ? The dead don't cry.
Look at me. I'm not going to let anyone hurt you. You have to trust me.
I do trust you...
But you can't protect me forever. Sooner or later, Draim'll get to me. I have to find out what's on that crystal.
Arissa, I don't think you can count on whatever's on that crystal to get you out of this.
If that's true, then I don't have a chance.
Yes, you do. If you testified against Draim, you could put him in prison for the rest of his life.
You could get immunity for any crimes you may have committed, start a new life.
Testify against Draim... ? I'd never make it to the witness stand.
I will take personal responsibility for your safety. I don't care how long it takes, if I have to ask for a leave of absence, I will.
You'd do that for me? Why?
I've done things I'm not proud of, too. You worked for Draim, I worked for the Cardassians. But I never had the courage to walk away. You did. I admire that.
You're going to have to give me a minute to get used to this... I've never been admired for anything other than the way I look.
Most people can't see past the surface... especially when what they see is so beautiful.
I'm sorry, I merely meant --
Don't apologize.
Well... I'm going to see if they've made any progress decoding the crystal. Make yourself comfortable. I'll check in on you later.
I'm not going anywhere.
Let me help you with that...
Extraordinary... you just jumped out of an airplane at twenty thousand feet, and there's not a hair on your head out of place...
Odo... ?
Sorry to interrupt. I need to talk to you. Alone.
Of course.
Driver, stop the car.
(opening the door for the woman) We'll just be a minute...
Isn't that the woman I was supposed to steal away from Falcon?
Well, yes... -- but since you didn't show up...
You swept her off her feet.
Sort of.
Tell me... how did you know she was interested?
It's that kind of program. What's this all about, Odo?
You didn't come here to talk about women. Did you?
Oh. This is about "bedroom eyes," isn't it?
Who told you about her? Kira?
No.
Dax.
Actually it was Miles.
If people are talking, it's only because they care. You put on a good front, but anyone who really knows you can see that you're lonely.
If you're interested in this woman, you have to let her know.
I can't...
Why not?
What if I... what if she...
Rejects you?

She might. But you can't go through life trying to avoid having your heart broken. If you do, it'll break from loneliness, anyway. So you might as well take a chance. If you don't, she'll move on, and you'll never know what you might have had.
And living with that would be worse than having a broken heart, believe me.
We're almost done, darling...
Car trouble, Mister Bashir? Oh. Hi, Odo.
I should go. Thank you, Doctor.
This isn't fair, Chief. Odo and I were talking.
Didn't anyone ever tell you you shouldn't stop for hitchhikers?
Hello.
Hello. I didn't expect to find you awake.
I couldn't sleep.
If the bed isn't comfortable --
The bed is fine.
I guess you have no news for me.
Dax is going to run a quantum scan on the crystal in the morning.
I'd like to be there. I might be able to help.
I'll arrange it.
I'm not in your way, am I?
No, not at all. Usually, I just read for an hour or two.
What are you reading?
It's a detective novel.
Have you figured out who did it yet?
By the third page.
Well... I should let you get back to your book.
I don't really feel like reading.
Maybe we could talk for a while?
What do you want to talk about?
Tell me more.
I could swear that when we first met, you're nose had a little curve right here.
I tend to look a little different every day...
(tracing the lines on his forehead) You always manage to make these the same.
I pay special attention to my scowl... an air of stern suspicion is very important in my line of work.
What? Why are you looking at me like that?
I'm trying to figure something out.
Tell me, maybe I can help.
I've never been able to let my guard down with a woman... until now. I was wondering what makes you different.
Wait a minute... are you saying you've never been with anyone before?
Not a humanoid. Once, on my homeworld, I had an experience that you might consider sexual.
But you've never been with a woman before?
You seem surprised.
I am.
I'm glad to hear it... I must've done all right.
You did better than all right.
I don't ever want to leave this room... can we just stay here forever?
I wish we could...
Arissa, everything is going to work out.
I wish I could believe that. But I know what the Orion Syndicate does to people who turn against the organization. I don't want to spend the rest of my life looking over my shoulder.
I'm sorry. I shouldn't have brought it up. Let's just... be together.
All right...
Tell me more about this encounter you had on your homeworld...
It was with another changeling. Our bodies became... intermingled.
Sounds nice. Too bad I'm not a changeling...
We shouldn't let that stop us...
She spent the night in his quarters.
That's because he had her in protective custody.
Come on, Nerys. He could've put her somewhere else.
You know how Odo is, he likes to be thorough.
It's more than that.
Commander --
What makes you say that?
Instinct.
Jadzia --
What?
You asked to be told when the sensor array became available.
Thank you. Odo and a woman -- it was bound to happen sooner or later, right?
I suppose.
You can begin your experiment at any time.
I'm talking to Kira.
You are not talking, you are gossiping. And besides, Odo is capable of taking care of himself.
Don't shout across the room, if you want to gossip with us, come over here.
Where's Odo? He asked me to arrange a conference with Starfleet Intelligence at oh-eight hundred.
I guess he's running late.
He's never late.
He never spent the night with a woman before.
A woman? That's nice. Isn't it?
Good morning.
Starfleet Intelligence is ready when you are.
Did you see the look on Odo's face? I'm telling you, something happened.
I talked to Draim. The woman asked to make a deal -- she gives us the crystal, Draim lets her go.
So we don't have to kill her?
Don't be stupid. As soon as we've got the crystal, she dies.
Oh. (thinks for a beat, shrugs) Makes sense.
There's an enormous amount of data stored inside the crystal, and a lot of it is quantum level information.
There goes our plan.
What do you mean?
